But with case rates higher in England than Scotland, and deaths still higher than , a day, the PM is so far sticking firmly to his plan. He says heaposll bring forward a lockdown easing plan in the week of February , with no changes before March . What is your view  Have your say in the comments section below Reports - denied as b*****ks by his allies - suggest Chancellor Rishi Sunak is pushing for measures to ease as soon as deaths are down, believing there may soon be a fat lady sings moment when cases stay high but deaths plunge due to vaccine immunity kicking in. But with more easily transmissible mutant strains emerging in the UK, and the nation passing the grim milestone of , deaths, scientic advisors are urging caution. The government has also failed to introduce forced quarantine in hotels for Brits ing from  aposred listapos countries where there are new iants. It was promised at the end of January but may only launch on February . The vaccine will be key. Even though care home residents have now been offered the jab, Care Minister Helen Whately has suggested normal visits may only resume once most have had their second dose in April. Meanwhile, Englandaposs Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty has said itaposll only be after all over-s have got the jab that pressure on the NHS will signicantly reduce. The original plan was to get all over-s their first dose by the end of April. But in a glimmer of hope, privately Whitehall sources believe that could happen quicker. Some murmurings even claim every UK adult could be offered both doses by the end of August. So with all these iables at play, what might the lockdown exit roadmap look like  And how will the next few months go down  Hereaposs everything we know - or can guess - so far. January  Tory ministers claimed they had met their target to offer a first dose of the vaccine to all residents in Englandaposs care homes. However, more than  care homes had not yet been fully reached because they had an active outbreak. There was also confusion about how many staff had had a jab and the government refused to provide firm figures. A minister said staff were still being worked through, only for another minister to claim the staff target had been met. Despite the vaccine breakthrough, normal care home visits are not expected to resume for months. Except for exceptions like deathbed visits, they have to be conducted outdoors or through pods or screens. February  This is the date of the review of the third lockdown in England, as set by the Prime Minister at the start of January. By this date the Government should have a clearer picture of whether the lockdown has worked. Plans will be brought forward the following week. Importantly, this is also the deadline for offering the first dose of a vaccine to all million of the most vulnerable people in the UK.  They are all over-s all elderly care home residents and their carers all shielders and frontline NHS and social care staff. After this, officials will move on to administering first doses to the next priority groups - all over-s and younger “at risk” groups. Separately, around this time the government’s advisors are meant to rule on how priority will work for the final phase of the vaccine rollout - in other words, whether teachers, shop workers and police will get it first. Finally, February  is the rumoured date when hotel quarantine will finally come into force. It was announced three weeks earlier. Brits ing from  aposred listapos countries, where travel for non-Brits is already banned, will have to be in guarded hotels for  days. February   Boris Johnson said the lockdown exit roadmap will be published in the week of February . It will go before Parliament for debate. Reports - downplayed by No - have claimed the roadmap will set out three stages of lting lockdown from March . Mr Johnson and Englandaposs Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty have confirmed lockdown will not be lted all at once - but will instead involve a number of stages. However, the Prime Minister has indicated England will notto the regional apostieredapos system and instead ease out of lockdown all at once - contrary to what he said before. The first actual easing of restrictions isnapost expected until March - despite Scotland potentially opening schools from February . February  It appears this is when the lockdown roadmap will be debated in Parliament. The government has announced the Commons will debate a proposal for a national education routemap for schools and colleges in response to the Covid- outbreak. March   This is the earliest date schools could reopen in England, according to Mr Johnson. He said the roadmap will give two weeksapos notice to parents, pupils and school staff. It has been reported some year groups may go back first - most likely primary schools and those in secondaries that have exams this year. Only after this will non-essential shops, pubs and the like start to reopen, but advisers have said we need a clear two-week break between each new thing opening to check itaposs going okay. The reason for the delay from February  is that it takes three weeks for immunity to have some effect. March Schools will be the first to reopen, but quickly other minor aspects of lockdown could be lted - such as the ban on mixing with others from outside your home. We might see a reinstatement of the rule of six, allowing you to meet up with five others, for example. That will set out whether you can meet with people in your garden, in public, in your home or where and how many people at once. March  This is the date the current lockdown legislation for England ends. MPs will have to approve any extension to lockdown rules after this date. By this point, the process of giving first doses to people aged  to  and younger ‘at risk’ groups is meant to be well under way. Officially the target to offer these million people their first dose is the end of April, but sources have claimed it could go quicker. A government source told the Mirror it is possible all million will be offered their first dose by the middle or end of March.  There are a couple of things that could scupper the timetable at this point. Firstly, this is around the time when the NHS has to start giving hundreds of thousands of people per day their second dose. That could gum up capacity and make it harder to get new people through the door for first doses. However, ministers believe the vaccine supply is secure to this point. Vaccine Minister Nadhim Zahawi said on February : “Our limitation is the vaccine supply. It remains stable and good. I can see week by week supply all the way through to the end of March, which is good news.” April  Easter Sunday - and a time when Boris Johnson claimed restrictions would be substantially lted. “I think we can certainly look forward to a very, very dferent world in this country, from Easter onwards,” the PM said. This date is gaining traction because ministers and Chris Whitty have suggested that, after over-s get the jab, itaposll be safe to lt many restrictions. This is around the time many over-sapos immunity should begin kicking in. But the PM has repeatedly over-promised on this in the past. If restrictions aren’t lted in a big way by this point, you could expect a battle between Tory lockdown sceptics and the PM. UK Hospitality has called for pubs to reopen from this weekendcase rates are falling, but others say itaposs far too soon. April  According to The , the Governmentaposs roadmap will make sure there is not a sudden increase in community transmission, by staggering what opens when. A Whitehall source told the : If schools do open in March, and the priority is certainly to open schools first, then it will mean other things have to remain closed for some time. “We have to avoid the situation last time where theof schools meant far greater household mixing across the board. “So that means weaposd be likely to wait at least another month for non-essential retail, and a month beyond that at least for pubs and restaurants. That would mean early April is likely when non-essential retail, such as clothes and electronics shops, could reopen, possibly coinciding with Easter.  The Government could also use this Easter break to kickstart tourism, allowing for the reopening of some tourist attractions and possibly accommodation. Travel rules could be eased - within the UK - to allow for staycations. Previously Boris Johnson claimed restrictions would be substantially lted by Easter “I think we can certainly look forward to a very, very dferent world in this country, from Easter onwards,” the PM said. April  This is a back-of-a-cigarette-packet figure being touted by some as when lockdown could start properly easing. Itaposs come about because experts say lockdown measures can only lt in a big way once first doses are offered to all over-s. Vaccines Minister Nadhim Zahawi refused to say when that would happen - and the official target date is April . But some have calculated that,the government continues at its current required rate of million first doses every  days, all over-s and vulnerable groups would be all offered a first dose by around March . It takes around three weeks for immunity to take effect, which supposedly takes us to April . This is not a reliable figure, though. Firstly it relies on there being no lumps or gaps in supply. Secondly it misses out the rather massive fact that, from March, weaposll be giving millions of people second doses at the same time. Englandaposs Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty said: From March, weaposll be starting to re-vaccinate as well as the first vaccines, and that will inevitably slow things down. April  This is the latest date by which all over-s and at-risk groups are meant to have been offered their first dose, according to the NHS. m people should have been offered a first vaccine dose by this date. Millions more will be getting their second dose at the same time. After that, the NHS will move onto giving first doses to the final, lowest-priority group - all adults under  without major health issues. These m people will be sorted into priority groups and it’s thought teachers and other key workers will be put first. Meanwhile, care home visits may only properly resume around this date. Care home residents were offered a first dose by the end of January - but it takes  weeks to get a second dose. And care minister Helen Whately said: I know relatives are desperate for normal visiting and I am determined that happen as soon as it is safe, but most care home residents must have their second dose. May  Under theplan, early April could be the earliest that pubs, restaurants and other hospitality businesses would be allowed to reopen. The date could coincide with the May Bank Holiday, usually a big money date for pubs and tourism businesses. SAGE experts have previously said May would be a safer date for reopening the hospitality sector -infection rates can be brought down. If all the over s and most vulnerable have had their first vaccine dose by April, then May would be seen as substantially safe for easing lockdown further. May will also see elections across the country, meaning the Government will want to have eased restrictionspossible to allow this to happen. Mark Harper, chairman of the Covid Recovery Groupof lockdown-sceptic Tories, said he thought the Government could get rid of restrictions completely by the end of May. Asked on BBC Radio aposs World At One: Back-of-the-envelope calculations that I did based on two million doses a week, you could get the top nine groups, first doses, and the top four groups, second doses, all done by the end of May. So it seems to me by the time you get to the end of May, no later than that, you should be in a position to get rid of restrictions completely. But obviously it does depend on the rollout of the vaccine. July Second doses should be rounded off for the middle priority group, the over-s. It’s also one predicted date for all adults to finish being offered their first dose. Officially the target is September for this, but government sources told the Sundayit could be as soon as July. If all adults have had a vaccine by this date, then summer travel becomes more of a possibility. There will still be a aposred listapos of countries requiring quarantine and the Foreign Office will have a list of countries people shouldnapost travel to at all.  Foreign holidays will depend as much on the rules of other countries as of the UK Government - which will be determined by how much of their population has been vaccinated and how safe they view the UK to be. Spain appeared to say it could be closed to tourists throughout the summer season - although it later rolled back on that. July  Rules allowing councils to close pubs, restaurants, shops and parks expire on this date - so it is the current latest date we could see ongoing closures in England. August Tentative reports suggest officials are hopeful that, by the end of August, all adults in the UK will have had both doses of the vaccine. This would allow a major reopening of society. But officially the target is only to offer all adults a first dose by September. Chris Whitty said August is at the very optimistic end. Scientists are hopeful though. SAGE member Andrew Hayward said: I think what weaposll see is a phased opening up as the vaccination levels increase, and then we will be more or less back to normal for the summer, I would imagine. September The Government aims to have offered a first dose of the vaccine to every adult by September. Tory ministers have pledged all UK adults will be offered their first dose by this month. Dominic Raab said the target was by September”, telling Sky News: If we can do it faster than that, great, but thataposs the roadmap. September  The start of autumn. Professor Chris Whitty said some coronavirus restrictions could be in place until the autumn while the NHS Chief Executive Sir Simon Stevens said restrictions would be lted between the spring and summer - with summer ending on this date. October The start of flu season, and mass vaccination against that disease. This may be combined with the re-vaccination of the most vulnerable against coronavirus at the end of . Scientists are unsure how long immunity will last from having the jab - with estimates of anything from five to nine months. That means those currently getting the jab will likely need to have another one in October to protect them through next winter. AstraZeneca and Oxford have said vaccine booster shots against new coronavirus iants should be ready by this month. We just have to hope a new iant hasnapost taken hold by that point. December  Even once all UK adults are given a first dose, second doses could go on until Christmas due to a -week gap. That would mean maximum protection would only be given to the maximum size of population about a year from now. Even after this is complete, there are many questions about where the UK’s Covid response goes from here. The vaccine will not eliminate coronavirus completely, and new iants could emerge that challenge how effective it is. That suggests travel restrictions could continue to exist into winter , as well as some of the less invasive restrictions we’ve got used to. Scientic advisors have suggested this could include, for example, wearing masks on public transport.

SAGE’s Andrew Hayward said the inoculation programme offered a key to easing the lockdown. Figures tonight showed ,, people have received first doses. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: “Today we passed the threshold of one in five of the population who have been jabbed already.” The UK remains on track to complete jabs of the top four priority groups by February , he added.What is your view  Have your say in the comments sectionCoronavirus cases continued to fall, with , recorded – down % on a rolling seven-day average. And , Covid- patients were admitted to hospital, down %.The UK death toll rose by , down %, to ,. Prof Hayward, professor of ­infectious disease epidemiology and inclusion health research at University College London, believed the increase in vaccinations will plot a path out of the shutdown. He said: “Once the most ­vulnerable people, particularly those over- and those with chronic illnesses, are ­vaccinated then yes, I think we can see a signicantto normality. “I think what we’ll see is a phased opening up as vaccination levels increase. Then we’ll be more or less back to normal for the summer, I would imagine.”  Pressure is mounting on Boris Johnson to publish a lockdown exit plan. The PM has vowed to outline a strategy in the week beginning February .Schools will reopen first, with face-to-face lessons in England due to resume from March . Paul Hunter, professor of medicine at the University of East Anglia, said the rate of the fall in cases fuelled hopes curbs on households’ mixing could go next month – with pupils back before March . He said: “I think there could well be a case for opening schools sooner – I particularly think schools for children under  years of age, where the evidence that they contribute to the spread of the epidemic in the wider population is a lot lower.” Prof Hunter thought diners couldto restaurants “probably around the same time [March], maybe April”.It comes amid claims Rishi Sunak told allies Britain was approaching a “fat lady sings moment” for the easing of curbs. An “ally” of Mr Sunak quoted by the Daily ­ said: “Rishi remains where he has been throughout the pandemic – he is pro-opening as quickly and as safely as possible. This needs to be the last time that we do this.” Labour said the reported claims, less than a month before the Budget, were “so ­irresponsible”.Shadow Public Health Minister Alex Norris said Mr Sunak’s ­“disastrous ­decision to block public health ­measures [last year] helped give Britain the worst death toll in Europe and the worst recession of any major economy”. Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury Bridget Phillipson tweeted: “You can’t protect the economy during a pandemic unless you protect public health.” However, a source close to the Chancellor said they were ­“absolutely not things he would say”.  Tory MP Mark Harper, chairman of the Covid Recovery Group of lockdown-sceptic Conservatives, claimed curbs could be lted by the end of May. He said: “Back-of-the-envelope calculations based on two million doses a week, you could get the top nine groups first doses, and top four groups second doses, all done by the end of May.” Mr Johnson’s spokesman said: “It remains the PM’s view we want to start easing lockdown restrictions and we are keen to do that from March .” NHS Providers chief executive Chris Hopson warned services were still at “full stretch” and cautioned against relaxing measures too early, adding “the NHS has barely crested the peak”. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAsylum seekers fleeing persecution are being given degrading food thataposs left them feeling sick, itaposs claimed. Charity West London Welcomehas shared pictures of the aposairline-likeapos meals provided to people living in emergency hotel accommodation. One appalling dinner included mash, peas and a bag of crisps while another consisted of congealed noodles. The charity claims families awaiting decisions on their asylum for months arenapost even allowed to use microwaves to heat food up and have to resort to boiling eggs in kettles. The Home Office has given a number of its contracts to manage temporary hotels housing asylum-seekers to the same firm running the Napier Barracks in Folkestone, Kent, that has been hit by a fire and a Covid- outbreak. Clearsprings Ready Homes was given a budget of £ per person for three meals a day, WLW claims, with the charity comparing the food to the free school meals scandal.A Labour MP has branded the food degrading and has written to Home Secretary Priti Patel in protest at the callous treatment.A Home Office spokesperson said asylum seekers are provided with a choice of three meals a day in line with NHS nutrition guidelines.What do you think  Share your views in the comments below... Asylum-seekers are legally barred from finding work or accessing benefits, which could allow them make their own food in the hotels. But they have also been banned from using the hotelsapos kitchens, including microwaves, and were forced to toss out donated ready-meals they could not cook, charityaposs director Joanne MacInnes told the Mirror. Pictures of the unimpressive meals shared by the charity include a stew covered in sweetcorn that was given to a seven-year-old for lunch. Another picture of a packaged chicken burger was criticised for its ‘astonishing’ list of highly-processed ingredients.One tweet showing picture of a packaged dinner roll said: The adult’s meal is a cold patty that they’re unable to heat up given that they have no access to any cooking facilities whatsoever. “Imagine never being able to warm up your food ” Ms MacInnes claimed asylum-seekers in London hotels her charity was helping were left boiling donated eggs and pot noodles in their roomsapos kettles. Clearsprings has had a Home Office contract to run accommodation services across London, Englandaposs South and the Wales regions since . The charity has been fielding complaints from asylum-seekers around the capital - some of whom have lived in the hotels since last June. Their allegations include being given half-heated chicken they are afraid to eat in case of food poisoning.  The charity says a number of asylum-seekers have shown them doctoraposs notes saying the food is making them sick due to a lack of nutrition, also alleging they were only given only three pieces of fruit a week per person and never any salad. Asylum-seekers able to find a way into independent accommodation are given £ a week for living costs by the Home Office but those in the temporary accommodation are given just £ a week, the charity said. WLW is calling for the hotel food supplies to be overhauled, and for the employment ban and aposno recourse to public fundsapos policies to be scrapped for asylum-seekers. Ms MacInnes said people fleeing war and persecution deserved a better welcome to Britain. “These are some of the most vulnerable people in society who arrive here with trauma and PTSD, she said. The meals they were being served were not nutritious and left people hungry, she added.  “There’s never been salad, there’s never been anything fresh or crunchy. We’ve not seen that in a single meal, she said. They average around three pieces of fruit a week - always bananas or oranges - that’s the only fresh food they are given.The point is people have been in these hotels for up to eight months and this is what they are eating.”Clearsprings has been criticised recently over conditions at Napier Barracks, which was hit by a mass Covid- outbreak last month. A fire at the facility last week followed protests by asylum-seekers at the conditions there. The incident led Ms Patel to accuse asylum-seekers of setting the fire, in a statement claiming the aposshocking scenesapos showed they were aposnot grateful aposfor British taxpayersapos hospitality. Hammersmith Labour MP Andy Slaughter has written to the Home Secretary, demanding an explanation and branding the meals pictured by the charity appalling and degrading.  He sought answers on costs and urged urgent checks to the nutritional quality of the disgraceful food being served. Mr Slaughter said: “They can’t rely on takeaways as they don’t have any means… it’s clearly an issuethey are being given food that needs to be heated up and they’re not allowed to do that. It’s an expression of the callousness of this government.” He accused the Home Secretary of permitting poor conditions as part of the Tories’ ‘hostile environment’ policy. Mr Slaughter said: “It’s asthere are people in the Home Office deciding new ways to be nasty to asylum-seekers, as a part of Patel’s strategy to put a stop people from coming here to claim asylum.”

Bethany Skinner, , was pulled from the water in Bognor Regis, West Sussex, on February , . The Plymouth University art graduate, originally from Taunton, Somerset, died in hospital two days later after suffering brain damage from a lack of oxygen. An inquest heard Bethany had been working at Butlinaposs to pay off her student overdraft and was due to move to China to teach children English. She had been out at Sheiks nightclub with a group of friends who all worked at Butlinaposs on the night of her death. Crawley Coroneraposs Court heard Bethany and her boyfriend of three months had an argument in the club and were asked to leave by security staff. In a statement, the bouncer who escorted Bethany outside said she had told him: I have been trying to please him all night but I canapost do anything right. Giving evidence Bethanyaposs boyfriend Philip Erickson said: We had a little bit of an argument, she said I was spending too much time with the boys, she was saying she would go home. I said I didnapost want her to go home. When she tried to go I grabbed her arm to stop her, and the bouncer thought it was a bigger argument and fight so they told us to leave. I would say that I was tipsy. She was on the same level, like drunk, tipsy. Mr Erickson said they left the club and Bethany walked ahead of him and down onto the beach, shouting at him to leave her alone. She then stood with the sea around her legs while he stood a few paces away. He said: The tide was very tough. There were lots of waves. She was stood up to her shins where the water is and saying she would go in. It all happened so quickly. The wave knocked her a little bit, she was stumbling. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mutation of coronavirus found in Liverpool has spread to new areas as the public are told get tested. When Health Secretary Matt Hancock talked yesterday in Parliament about a Covid- aposmutation of concernapos found in Liverpool yesterday it reportedly took some in the city by surprise. And the iant - of which Mr Hancock said  cases had been found in the Merseyside city - has now been found in Preston and West Lancashire , say local health officials. People living in those areas are being urged to take a Covid- testthey are feeling unwell, with symptoms including a cold, mild flu and headaches. It comes after a host of postcodes started door-to-door surge testing after cases involving the South Africa Covid iant, feared to better evade vaccines, were detected. Dr Sakthi Karunanithi, director of public health and wellbeing at Lancashire County Council, said: If you live in Preston or West Lancashire and youaposre feeling under the weather, please get a Covid test. It doesnapost matteryou donapost have the three classic symptoms of a fever, loss of taste or smell, or a cough - even a headache could be an indication you may have this mutation. Understandably, some residents may be concerned but all viruses mutate over time so this should not cause any further alarm. Alongside our partners, please rest assured that we are monitoring the situation closely. It is important to stress that there is currently no evidence that this mutation alone causes more severe illness or is more transmissible. The Mirroraposs sister title the Liverpool Echo reports how Mr Hancockaposs announcement of the  cases, without offering any more detail, led to a slew of headlines and anxious questions about whether this was a new mutation making its way around the city. But the confirmation of the mutation was not exactly new to reporters in the area, as the paper had revealed that Public Health England was investigating a cluster of cases involving the EK mutation of the virus, that had been linked to a number of staff members from Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital. While confirmation of the mutation was not new, the number mentioned by the Health Secretary was. It would appear that those five confirmed cases have become , and that is what is concerning officials.  Plans are being worked up in terms of responding to any potential growth in the spread of this mutation and it is understood this is likely to involve enhanced testing. This mutation, known as EK, is already present in both South African and Brazilian coronavirus iants. The cluster in Liverpool has the same mutation but relate to the original strain of coronavirus that has been around since the start of the pandemic. Itaposs not a new iant, it is a mutation that has been previously detected in aposiants of concern.apos  A iant is a term used for genetically distinct viruses that have specic mutations that can be tracked and followed to identy clusters emerging and growing in the population. There are many thousands of these. They are identied as a iant of interest or concern when they have a particular constellation or cluster of mutations that are concerning, orthey are associated with changes in the virus. The majority of iants emerge and subsequently become extinct due to stopping transmission by testing, contact tracing and isolation. Scientists can also identy mutations of interest which arise independently in multiple dferent genetically distinct viruses.  Pubic Health England detected a cluster of linked cases with this mutation in Liverpool and are investigating further. Public Health England say there is currently no evidence that this mutation alone causes more severe illness or is more transmissible, which is good news. However it is reported to result in weaker neutralisation by antibodies in lab experiments and so aposmay need further investigation to understand more on immune response and how well vaccines work against it.apos

story: NewsMiracle baby born after mums five miscarriages and dad battles brain cancerEXCLUSIVE: Kate Meakin feared she would be a widow looking after her son when her husband was diagnosed with a brain tumour - but now he is recovering and they have a beautul baby daughtermirrorShareCommentsByCarol Dyce:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBaby Autumn was born in October after her dad had his sperm frozen following his brain tumour diagnosis" %, rgba, rgba, url"Our free email newsletter sends you the biggest headlines from news, sport and showbizWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs besotted new mum Kate Meakin feeds her baby daughter, Autumn, with big brother, Austin, looking on adoringly, she loves every minute as a family of four. But rewind two years and Kate feared she’d be left a widow at  bringing up their little boy alone, after their world fell apart when husband Phil was diagnosed with a brain tumour. Determined not to give up their dream of expanding their family, just three days after Phil’s diagnosis, he had his sperm frozen before starting chemotherapy. And that act of hope in the most devastating week of the couple’s le resulted in daughter Autumn - their “light at the end of the tunnel” – born on October , . Phil is now recovering well and the couple feel blessed they’ve got a second chance of happiness. “Our little girl is a symbol of hope and new beginnings for us as a growing family,” said Kate, , from Surrey. “It’s amazing knowing that Autumn was conceived with sperm frozen in the week her daddy was diagnosed with a brain tumour. After everything we’ve been through, for the first time in years we’re excited about le and our future looks bright.” Autumn’s birth was even more poignant as Kate had suffered six miscarriages trying to give Austin, now four – who was conceived in the couple’s first IVF attempt – the precious gt of a sibling. She lost three babies before Phil’s diagnosis and three while he was going through treatment using frozen embryos from treatment the first time round with Austin. “It was an emotional rollercoaster,” said Kate. “Phil was undergoing radiotherapy while I was having injections to stimulate my egg production. “I had three miscarriages over six months during his treatment, the first at six-and-half weeks and the other two at five weeks.” The couple decided to give having another baby “one final go” using the sperm Phil, , had frozen in the same week doctors told him he had a brain tumour.The couple’s ordeal started in November  when Phil was diagnosed with a brain tumour after suffering severe headaches, dizziness and tingling and numbness on his left-hand side. Doctors put the symptoms down to a sinus infection and then vertigo. Phil’s headaches intensied and sometimes he’d have to go to bed because he was in so much pain and nauseous. After five months, he saw a private GP through work and was referred for a scan, which revealed a large tumour spanning both hemispheres of his brain. Phil received the devastating news on his own as he hadn’t spotted the consultant’s email that they’d found an “anomaly” on his brain, and to bring someone with him. “He’d had an early appointment before work and I was woken up at am by the phone ringing,” said Kate. “Phil said, ‘It’s not good news, I’ve got a lump in my head that shouldn’t be there.’ “I think I stopped breathing. I was cuddled up with Austin and just couldn’t take in his words. He was a fit, healthy -year-old, brain tumours weren’t even on our radar. “The doctor told him to go home. On the train, Phil was on the phone to me and we were both crying. I went to meet him at the station with Austin and we clung to each other.” Kate couldn’t help herself fearing the worst. “My first thought was, ‘I’m going to be a widow at ,” she said. “Austin was only two and I was convinced Phil wouldn’t see him grow up and that we’d never have any more children. One minute le was normal, the next it was scary and unknown.”  Two days later, the couple went to see Phil’s consultant who broke the news he thought Phil’s tumour was cancerous. “We were told that Phil had to have surgery soon or he could die,” said Kate. “My mind went spiralling into a dark place as I thought we were going to lose him imminently. “Phil was so shocked he nearly got sick. “Then I asked about freezing Phil’s sperm as it was so important to both of us to have another child. “On the way home on the train everyone was enjoying their night out while he was white as a sheet and I was hysterical. “Back at home, I was straight on google and read that Phil’s prognosis may be  months, which made me feel even worse.” They coped by going into practical mode. “Phil dealt with our finances and I had a crash course in where everything was,” said Kate. “We didn’t have wills and did those, too. “Everything was sorted out in four days flat before Phil’s surgery.” Austin was only two when Phil was diagnosed but the couple were open as possible with him. “We told him, ‘Daddy has a poorly head’ and that he was having treatment to make him better,” said Kate.

Gemma Robinson, , suffered a fractured eye socket at the hands of her jealous ex-lover Joseph Falconer, . The mum-of-two was found dead just hours before the thug tried to secure his release from prison on bail. One month later he admitted inflicting GBH and has now been jailed for three years and four months. Gemma’s family, who watched the sentencing while holding a photo of her in court, say the term is not long enough. Sister Kirsty Robinson, , said: “She’s taken her le because of what he has done. That’s not justice. “He is  per cent to blame. Gemma was very outgoing, very friendly, popular but he left her unrecognisable as a person. “She was crying at night, struggling to get up in the mornings and be a mum, and was petried of coming to court and facing him.  “She wanted to face him and look strong but she was petried. She was a completely dferent person.” Fitness instructor Gemma started a relationship with railway worker Falconer in  but they split in January . Maidstone Crown Court was told one month earlier he had assaulted her and received a conviction for battery and criminal damage. Falconer later turned up at Gemma’s home and by October  she had agreed he could stay on her sofa.  Prosecutor Vivian Walters said: “He paid no rent and she bought and provided all his food. “His behaviour became increasingly controlling and he started to question her about where she was going and who she was going to see - similar behaviour to when they were in a relationship.” Jealous Falconer phoned and texted as much as  times after Gemma went for a night out with a friend. When she ed to her flat in Dartford, Kent, he forced her into a shower cubicle before punching her repeatedly in the face.  As well as the eye socket fracture, she suffered cuts and bruising to her head, face, arms, neck and chest. The brutal attack took place in November  and a charge of GBH with intent was initially denied by Falconer. However, one month after Gemma’s death last July he pleaded guilty to the lesser offence of inflicting GBH. Falconer, of St Leonards on Sea, East Sussex, who was subject to a restraining order at the time of the attack, was jailed on Wednesday.  He offered his sincere condolences to Gemma’s family through his barrister while appearing on video link from prison. Passing sentence, Recorder Matthew McDonagh told Falconer: “You involved yourself in what can only be described as a gratuitous and violent attack upon Gemma Robinson. “You held her neck, affecting her ability to breathe, and punched her repeatedly in the face, ending the assault with the indignity of spitting on her.

The sheet was discovered by Rosa Beckerton’s husband Peter, , while he was refurbishing an old piece of furniture for a client. It is dated February , , and appears to be written by an -year-old girl imagining the state of the world in . She correctly predicts a huge sht in technology and even forecasts the Zoom revolution. Describing her husband’shome from work she writes: “’Hello dear,’ he said to me. ‘I’ve just got to ring up my friend on the telephone’.What do you think about the schoolgirlaposs predictions  Let us know in the comments“’Well you’d better tidy yourself up a bit,’ I said. “In  the telephone was a square box thing with a resiver [sic] on top of it. “But now it is still a resiver [sic], but you can see the people you are talking to, for there is a screen where you can see the people. It is a bit like a television.” Upholsterer Peter found the note stuffed down the back of a sofa which was sent to him for restoration after being bought second-hand.  Rosa, , from Peterborough, Cambs., decided to make the it public in case the author, who would now be aged around , is still alive. She said: “When my husband showed it to me I couldn’t believe it. I thought oh my god, look at this. “It was just so interesting, because looking at it today she’s got a lot of her predictions kind of right - but in her childish innocent way she thought it would all happen in ten years.  “I just wanted to share it in the hopes that maybe the author might see it and recognise it. “My husband has found all sorts of rubbish down the side of sofas and furniture before - but never anything as interesting as this.” The letter is unnamed but comes complete with a teacher’s corrections and comments in red pen - including the verdict ‘Good’.  It begins: “The year is , the time is half-past moon dust. Here I am twenty-one years of age, sitting in a cushion of air. “I remember when I was  years old and I was at school, things have changed since then. “For instance, the television has changed. “In  it was a square box with knobs in front of it. Now it is a big screen with knobs on your chair arm to switch it on and off.” The schoolgirl imagines that she is a married bank worker. She says in times past she would have “prepared tea” ready for her husband to come home. But she adds: “All we have is a piece of chewing gum to eat. You may think that we have not enough to eat but you are wrong, because this piece of chewing gum is food.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe first delivery of much-needed equipment for lockdown school children arrived this week as parents and teachers praised the Mirror’s Help a Child to Learn campaign. Colouring pens, biros, paper, glue sticks, hand sanitiser and folders were among items delivered to Cubitt Town Junior School on the Isle of Dogs in East London. Head teacher Robyn Bruce told how the stock was “vital” for younger children home learning in deprived areas, many of who do not have access to the basics. The Mirror, in a joint appeal with the National Education Union , is urging readers and firms to dig deep to help kids struggling to learn at home.Tell us your thoughts on the Help a Child to Learn campaign in the comments belowSchool mum Khadija Khatun, , lives on the th floor of a tower block with her husband and five children - aged , , ,  and . As she was handed items from the delivery, she told the Mirror: “It’s really hard at home. “The school gave us a computer, and that’s great, but we also need other things which we have to go and buy.  “We really need scissors, glue, paper and pens and this will be really useful for us, so I’m very grateful for it. “Sometimes shops I go to have run out of stock and we just don’t have enough to go around. “My  and -year-olds need this kind of equipment more, and we’re really thankful for it.  “My husband is furloughed at the moment and we find out in Aprilhe will go back to work.” Year  key worker and vulnerable children at the school were delighted to get their hands on the delivery. Mid-way through a science lesson Arsenal fan Bradie Adu-Yeboah, , told us: “It’s great because it’s all new.  “I’ll use it for all the work I have to do at home. “I have a colouring book so I will definitely be using the colouring pens.” His classmate Che’nai Quatromini, also , said: “I’m doing a moon project at home but I don’t have enough paper so I can use this for my background.  “I can also colour it in and use it for the moon. It will be really helpful.” This week’s delivery was a sample of what schools will have sent to them. Schools will get vouchers for either £, £, or £,, depending on their need. So far, there are  schools due to receive vouchers. Some £, has so far been raised in addition to the NEU’s £ million donation when we jointly launched the campaign last week.  At Cubitt Town Junior School, which also has an infants’ school attached to it, parents collect packages each Friday to help with home learning. The items bought with the vouchers will help create more packs for the children working from home and for those in need. Ms Bruce said: “The lower down the age groups you go, the more this kind of equipment is needed.  “Having paper, pens, scissors, and glue sticks at home is so important - and people don’t realise that parents sometimes don’t have them. “We had a parent whose child filled their homework in with a felt tip, and we could barely read it. I spoke to them and they did not have a pen at home. “It’s something that is taken for granted. “Of course they need computers and iPads and online learning is important, but it’s deeper than that.  “We’ve got families where there are lots of children in one small place and just feeding them is a struggle - and then we’re asking them to buy pens and paper and glue as well. “That’s why these deliveries will make such a dference and we thank the Mirror and the NEU for all they’re doing. “We also want pupils to have time away from the screen and to be creative. “The ide between those children who are from families which have this equipment and those from families who don’t will continue to grow unless we can ensure they all have the right means to learn.  “So much of our budget is being used to help pupils through the pandemic and there will be all sorts of extras to pay for once they , so these packages help us a lot,” said Ms Bruce. Kevin Courtney, Joint General Secretary of the NEU, said: “It is fantastic that Cubitt Town Junior School will benefit from the Help a Child to Learn campaign.

Mary Clark, , tragically lost her le to Covid- on Wednesday, January . She had allegedly told her doctor she was “getting worse, not better,” the Daily Record reports. Worried her health was in rapid decline she reportedly told her sisters she had no choice but “to lie here and die” after allegedly being passed from her GP to an NHS call handler on  on Monday, January  who reportedly advised her to manage symptoms with painkillers at home. Mary fell ill after a major outbreak of Covid at a factory which produces PPE with about  members of staff infected, reports say. Her family believes she never got the care she deserved. Mary leaves behind her fiance, Colin Grant,  who raced to the hospital after being told his partner had suffered a heart attack. Devastated sisters Heather Kirkwood, , Marish Fyfe,  and Margaret Clark,  have told how the loss of their sister known as ‘Wee Mary Doll’ has left “a big hole” in their hearts. Heather who also works at the factory along with sister Margaret reportedly noticed staff displaying symptoms in work before they were sent home. Mary who took a test on Monday, January  suffered from severe nausea and was “unable to move” without being sick. Worried her health was in rapid decline she is said to have told her sisters she had no choice but “to lie here and die” after reportedly being passed from her GP to an NHS call handler on  on Monday, January  who reportedly advised her to manage symptoms.But nine days after finding out she had tested positive for coronavirus, Mary was rushed to hospital after becoming “incoherent and breathless”.Despite being stabilised with oxygen - Mary suffered a fatal cardiac arrest caused by a blood clot in her lung - she died just three hours later. Heather told the Ayrshire Post: “Mary was meant toto her work on Thursday, instead she has died on Wednesday.  “It wasn’t for the lack of my sister asking for help from the local GPs and the ‘magic’  number, she did phone and she tried to get help. She added: “My sister passed away, of course we will never know what might have happenedthey just took a bit more time with her, would she still be here  “We are incensed by the whole thing, her GP are going to investigate how she was treated. “She said ‘I’m never going to phone any of them again and ask for help, I’m just going to lie here and die’ that’s what has happened. “On the Wednesday when we were talking to her she was incoherent and breathless, we knew this had gone far enough and we told her partner to phone an ambulance.” “They found out she had a blood clot in her lung that had travelled up to her heat and caused a cardiac arrest. David Jones said he paid £. for a Toshiba TV at the Tesco store in Ilkeston, Derbyshire, but discovered a LG model in the box when he got home.Even though the £ LG model was worth more, it came without a remote or any cables, NottinghamshireLive reports.The cleaner went back to the shop and demanded a refund, however he claims staff told him this was not possible. Mr Jones, who has learning dficulties, said: I nipped down to Tesco and went to look for TVs. Mr Jones said: I’ve been down three times with a couple of my friends and I’ve been down once by myself but they kept giving me some excuse. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK may never get fully back to how it was before the pandemic with masks worn for years, a top virologist has warned. While fears over mutant strains of Covid- could see Brits locked out of concert stadiums, sporting events and nightclubs with social distancing a key concern until into .Dr Phillip Gould of Coventry University says scientistsapos biggest worry is that new mutations in the coronavirus could threaten to move the UKaposs vaccine programme back.The more transmissible iant discovered in Kent has spread across the population and has out-competed the previous version, slowly taking over, said the expert, who is Coventry University’s Associate Head of School for Health and Le Sciences. It and the South African strain have raised fears among scientists that Covid- mutations could prove resistant to currently-approved vaccines. Dr Gould sounded a note of optimism, as amazing new technology developed by scientists allows them to adapt the vaccine, like we do every year with the flu vaccine. What is your view  Have your say in the comments section But while the UK is “lucky” to have vaccinated so many people at this point, and “well ahead of the game with vaccinations”, those hoping for ato full normality anytime soon may be disappointed, the doctor warns.And we may never go back to exactly how le was before the pandemic, with certain precautions becoming the norm forever - and social distancing until late this year, or even further. “I think social distancing will remain for a long time,” says Dr Gould. “Our way of le will change long-term. “Wearing a face mask in shops and on buses will remain for a long time, even after places and businesses have opened up. “The economy can get going in summer - but it won’t look like a normal summer. “We need long-term immunity and vaccination.” The wearing of masks and the fastidious washing of hands has already become a way of le in the UK, Dr Gould suggests, as it is in, for example, East Asian countries who experienced previous pandemics. “People’s perceptions have changed dramatically,” he says. “People go ‘where are my keys, where is my phone, and where is my mask’.” And while there is hope of some reprieve for bored Brits in the form of a summer holiday, it is unlikely that social events will be back with a bang anytime soon.  The virologist does not see Britain’s bustling nightle scene ing to the way it was this year. And there is little chance big sporting events will be able to enjoy big crowds for many months. “Not piling into places will remain the same for this year, definitely, long term,” he added. “We will have changed our culture dramatically, like not going to workyou’re feeling a bit ill - something many of us used to do.  “Are high risk places like nightclubs going to insist you have a test or vaccine before you go in   “Will we ever get the big football crowds back again  Long-term it’s possible.Dr Gould cited last yearaposs Cheltenham Festival - which has been blamed for a spike in cases in Gloucestershire after attracting , people between March  and  - and the Champions League match between Liverpool and Atletico Madrid - which went ahead on March  with thousands of away fans allowed in despite the Spanish capital emerging as a Covid epicentre - as big peaks in transmission.“We will be vaccinated, tests will be available, but I can’t see it until we are really confident that the vaccine programme is rolled-out - and that wonapost be until the end of the year, he added. Dr Gould also suggested that rapid lateral flow tests, which use a mouth and or nose swab, and can take about  minutes to give a result, will become very common before big events.  “We need to make sure the herd immunity is up, from the vaccination programme,” he adds. Dr Gould, whose research interests is based around the molecular characterisation of respiratory viruses, is optimistic that new vaccines can be made quickly. And he added the UK was very lucky with how many people have been vaccinated and that an enhanced vaccine infrastructure was now in place for years to come. The flexibility afforded by the UKaposs million doses of a vaccine from the French pharmaceutical company Valneva, that should become available later in the year and into , is another reason for optimism.  However, the Dr cautions that scientists face a constant race between the virus changing, which it will do, and our ability to predict that and make new vaccines. He adds: The worry is the more mutations we have. The more we can get reinfected and the less effective vaccines will be. The biggest worry is that they continue to circulate, the more chance it has to mutate again. At high levels it will continually mutate. The more it does - the bigger the chance vaccines will be less effective.  There are currently two Covid- vaccines being administered in the UK, but five more are in the pipeline and the government has million doses in total on order. Vaccines tested through clinical trials last year were tested on a population where the new strains were not circulating. But the Novavax vaccine, of which  million doses are expected to be delivered to the UK later this year, was trialled when the Kent strain was circulating. Approval by the UKaposs Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency is expected in several weeks.  But as scientists do not yet know how long immunity lasts, Dr Gould suggests vaccinations for the coronavirus could become a regular thing, like with the flu. He said: “We are going to have to continually vaccinate, and the Government is preparing for that. “Like with the flu, which is constantly changing and evolving, coronaviruses have been circulating in humans for s of years, but only caused minor infections up to now. “Getting vaccinated is really important offering really good protection for all strains over time.  “But over time, the immunity or protection may slow down, similar to other viruses. “It might be every year, or every two years you might have to go back for a boost, but the infrastructure is now in place, so that you will be able to do it. The current full national lockdown with the most strictest of restrictions could last at least another month, probably longer even after schools are open, Dr Gould feels, as numbers are still not good. Government is clearly reacting and detecting cases of these iants - whether they can control it is another thing, added the Dr.  We have got to treat all these coronaviruses the same, you must self-isolate, follow best practice. Because they are more effective at infecting people, any lockdown could be moved later simply because we have another iant in the mix. Numbers are low but it only takes one superspreader in these areas [where the iants are prevalent] to see numbers back up. Case numbers are going down but we’re still in a very critical point. We have got to get people vaccinated quickly, they have got to get their booster. As for hopes of a summer holiday, as Health Secretary Matt Hancock on Sunday said Brits will hopefully be in the middle of a happy and free summer in six monthsapos time, Dr Gould is also cautiously optimistic, saying a summer holiday in the UK could happen.I think we will be able to have a holiday, just a very dferent holiday than we are used to, whether UK-based or abroad, some restrictions will still be there, he added.The way the virus spreads in summer is dferent, and we will have more people vaccinated by then. There will be lots of hiccups and shortfalls, but people should be hopeful for summer.We are already seeing the good news stories with people celebrating they have been vaccinated.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailRoast dinner staple the Yorkshire pud has been named Britain’s favourite regional speciality. The humble flour, eggs and milk mix has risen to the top and beaten rivals from across the country from arch rival Lancashire hotpot and Devon and Cornwall’s cream teas to Cheddar cheese and Haggis. Figures from supermarket chain Tesco show sales of Yorkshire puds have soared  per cent year-on-year and one in five Brits reckon it’s the best part of a roast dinner. While they are eaten by millions at least once a week, almost half have never made one from scratch, the survey of more than , adults found.Are you a fan of the humble Yorkshire pudding  Let us know in the comments belowA quarter insist Yorkies must be served with gravy and more than one in  only tuck in on Sundays as part of the traditional roast and feel it’s wrong to have them midweek. Bizarrely, almost one in  revealed they had Yorkshire pud as a dessert with ice cream and chocolate sauce, fruit or marmalade. And one in  have used the versatile batter mix to make a pizza base, according to research ahead of National Yorkshire Pudding Day on Sunday .  Tesco’s executive chef Jamie Robinson said: “Making a good Yorkshire pudding can be tricky to master, but once you do there isn’t much better. The order in which you add the ingredients is key to how much they will rise.” He revealed the secret to great Yorkies is to beat the eggs then slowly add flour and finally add the milk a little at a time for a smooth mixture and let it rest - ideally overnight - for the best results.  Mr Robinson said: “I like to add some additional flavour into my Yorkshire pudding mixture, depending on what I am eating them with. For example,I am serving them with roast chicken then I will add some thyme into the batter. “Alternatively, when serving alongside roast beef, I will add in horseradish and rosemary - delicious.” But Yorkshire folk may raise an eyebrow over his brunch recipe of Yorkies filled with cream cheese, salmon, a runny poached egg and a sprinkling of chopped chives.

Faith Hill has shared her honest videos with her , followers on TikTok in order to educate others about the dangers of substance abuse.The -year-old from Missouri, in the US, was addicted to meth for six years and lived on the streets, the Daily Star reports. She says her drug use took its toll and she ended up losing several close friends to drugs. Faithaposs drug use also had an obvious effect on her body - she lost a shocking amount of weight and her teeth became eroded. Photographs show her thin as she got more and more addicted.Do you have a similarly inspirational story  Contact us on webnews@mirror  When she finally became sober she had to have all her teeth removed to make way for dentures. Her videos show her journey to becoming sober. In one clip, she explains: “I was on a six-year drug bender on methamphetamines. I was living on the streets, hotels, anywhere I could manage to lay my head at. “I obviously didnapost take care of my teeth. Well, I thought I did, but I didnapost. And it caused a lot of breakage, a lot of rotting, and I finally got them removed.”  Faith said she was arrested during her drug addiction, felt “hideous” and “miserable” during that period, and also attempted to take her own le, the Daily Star reports. But, after checking into rehab eight times, she finally managed to get sober last year. She has now got a new set of dentures and proudly shows off her new smile on her TikTok account.  In one clip, seen millions of times, she smiled without dentures in and said: “It’s like an empty smile, there’s nothing there.” Thousands of people regularly comment on her videos praising her for sharing the powerful story. “You are incredible and you inspire me,” one said. “You deserve nothing but the best.” Another wrote: “You are amazing. Thank you for your honesty and congratulations on your recovery.”

title: dundee manager james mcpake admits plugging the gap left by jordan mcghees absence is his biggest headache
story: James McPake admits “plugging the gap” in midfield left by Jordan McGhee’s absence is his biggest headache as he searches for Dundee’s winning formula.A defender throughout his career to date, McGhee has transformed himself into a box-to-box midfielder in recent weeks and played a major role in the Dark Blues’ upturn in form.That was until a shoulder injury forced him off early against Arbroath almost two weeks ago and has required surgery to sort the problem.The -year-old successfully underwent the operation on Monday morning but is expected to be out for a number of weeks.That has prompted McPake to look into the loan market for a temporary replacement and could see Celtic#s Ewan Henderson come in until the end of the season.Without McGhee, Dundee let their lead slip at Arbroath before losing - to Raith Rovers on Saturday.At Gayfield, McPake opted to use full-back Cammy Kerr in the middle of the park after he performed a similar role late on in the win over Hearts.Then at Stark’s Park it was a first start of the season for young midfielder Callum Moore, alongside Charlie Adam and Shaun Byrne.Moore had made a fleeting appearance in the cup win over Bonnyrigg Rose last month but enjoyed first-team experience under Jim McIntyre in the Premiership, playing five times in  .“We’ve seen in recent games what Jordan McGhee brings to our team so it is a blow but we need to find a way of plugging that gap,” said McPake.“We have players in this squad capable of doing that. It’s up to us to make sure we get it right.“It’s been a frustrating season for Callum. He’s one of the young ones with real first-team experience in the Premiership and he had been doing really well in pre-season. Then he picked up a chest infection and broke his foot in a friendly.“He’s had to be patient and had been doing really well in training. Last week we’d been working on how to play against Raith and he did really well. He deserved his chance.“He’s another good young player from the academy who can help the club.“We’ve had Max Anderson and Fin Robertson as well who’ve done great. Then there’s another group coming through – Sam Fisher made his debut on Saturday and Lyall Cameron has been doing well.“What we are looking for is to get that balance right in midfield in the hole left by Jordan McGhee’s injury.”The simplicity of Raith Rovers’ equalising goal at the weekend through former Dee Kyle Benedictus from a short corner was a huge frustration for McPake.Their second also came indirectly from another short corner, this time Reghan Tumilty firing in a superb -yarder after Dundee had cleared.That’s after conceding from a corner against Arbroath in the previous fixture and the Dundee boss admits “we need to get set-plays right”.“It was really frustrating to lose the first goal from a set-piece,” he added.“The second comes from the corner but ends up being an unbelievable strike.“Set-pieces are massive in football, at every level. As a player I always felt they were hugely important and that hasn’t changed now.“We were missing two of our most experienced players in Liam Fontaine and Lee Ashcroft – that’s not to say the two centre-backsdidn’t do well.“But that experienced allows them to organise and spot danger quicker, those goals might not have happened.“The third goal is a really good strike as well but we had chances ourselves. On another day, the result might have been dferent.“But we need to get set-plays right. It’s a bugbear of the players as well and we’re determined to sort it out.“We feel we have the best delivery in the league at the other end with Charlie Adam but we need to be better at defending them ourselves.” vw, px"  Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest

title: aberdeen airport accessibility group in bid for new members
story: A north-east organisation set up to help air passengers who require assistance has launched an appeal for new members.AccessABZ helps Aberdeen International Airport engage and consult with disability organisations and those who use its assistance service.The organisation wants new members to come forward to ensure the airport is an accessible environment for people of all abilities.It promotes continuous improvement and backs reviews of services to make sure the needs of those using them are met.Since it was set up in  the group has contributed to changes in the terminal, such as a new assistance desk at the main entrance.Terminal operations manager Kevin Douglas said: “Airports can be highly stressful environments for those with hidden disabilities or who need special assistance and Aberdeen Airport is committed to ensuring that all passengers using the facility are able to travel in as stress-free an environment as possible.“We appreciate that passengers who require assistance may have some anxieties in relation to Coronavirus.  We would like to reassure you that we have introduced a range of measures to help people travel safely. In addition, our assistance team will take the time to understand your needs and to make sure you are comfortable.“We are in close dialogue with many local and national disability organisations in order to keep improving the service we provide. We actively seek feedback on our facilities to ensure they are fit for purpose and welcome the input of iniduals and groups to shape our future provision.“This is a great opportunity for any person, charity or organisation to get involved and contribute which would benefit the airport and help us become a more accessible environment for all.”For more information on joining AccessABZ, email Fraser Bain at fraser.bain@aiairportFor as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. vw, px"

title: aberdeen food bank users praise charity volunteers for their support
story: Service users of a north-east charity have written letters thanking volunteers for their support.The beneficiaries, who wished to remain anonymous, have received food parcels from social enterprise CFINE throughout the Covid- pandemic.And it has now emerged the north-east public helped to raise more than £, for the Original  Christmas Appeal.The annual appeal aims to help families battling poverty in Aberdeen and throughout Grampian.Donations were collected in aid of CFINE for the appeal, which was backed by the Evening Express.The charity works to tackle poverty and build resilience through a range of support and services for and with disadvantaged, vulnerable, low-income iniduals, families and communities in the north-east of Scotland.A total of £,. was raised, enough to buy . tonnes of food # or , meals.CFINE has recorded demand for its services increase by a staggering % since the start of the pandemic, with the constant pressure that low-income families experience spiking over the festive season.In a letter to the charity, one service user wrote: #I am writing to you to express my massive thanks for your help.#I am in tears and wanted to let you know that you are doing an incredibly important job.#I never expected to get your support so quickly. Your care and professionalism is absolutely amazing during this unprecedented time.#Another beneficiary wrote: #Thank you so very much for organising this. We really feel that we have a leline now and this has helped to reduce our anxiety about the situation. I am so very grateful.#It is so heartening to see the community spirit and compassion that exists at times like this.#The charity asked people in the north-east to donate non-perishable foods, toiletries, and baby products, as well as monetary donations via its website. vw, px"  Lisa Duthie, CFINE chief executive, thanked the public for their support during an #incredibly challenging# year.She said: #On behalf of CFINE, I would like to thank Original  and the Evening Express for choosing us for their Christmas Appeal, as well as iniduals and local businesses who donated to the campaign.#The changes the past year has brought us have been incredibly challenging. Thanks to the generosity of people like yourselves, we have been able to continue our vital development work in local priority communities.#Your donations will go a long way in helping us extend a hand to anyone who is facing hardship. title: athletics aberdeen olympics hopeful zoey clark delighted with first 400 metres race after 15 month absence
story: Aberdeen’s Olympic m hopeful Zoey Clark is so happy to be back in competitive action after a gap of more than  months.The Great Britain international was one of a handful of elite athletes allowed to take part in a specially-arranged indoor meeting at the Emirates Arena last weekend.And she’llto Glasgow on Saturday for another race in the countdown to a possible appearance in next month’s European indoor championships in Poland.Last Saturday’s race was Clark’s first since helping Great Britain take fourth place in the women’s xm relay at the world outdoor championships at Doha in October .Her comeback proved to be a resounding success as she blasted round the tight bends of the Glasgow track to clock an impressive m time of .sec. That’s well inside the Euro qualying standard of ..Clark said: “It was exciting. After  months of no races, it was simply amazing. I was just buzzing the whole day and it was so good to be back racing again.“I must admit I was nervous, but it was nervous excitement rather than anything . It was a bizarre situation as there were only three events on the programme, a m, m and m.“When I walked in there was hardly anyone there. Only around  athletes and a similar number of officials and staff. All the seating had been pushed back, so it was very dferent from usual.“But I’m just so grateful to scottishathletics for putting the event on.”mdash scottishathleticsJanuary , Clark showed no signs of race rustiness as she delivered a composed performance which exceeded her expectations.She said: “There were only three of us in the race and I was the only girl. I was really happy with the performance as I’m fairly sure that’s the fastest opening m race I’ve run in any season.#That’s pleasing considering I wasn’t sure I’d actually remember how to race as it has been so long.“I knew from my training that I was in good shape, but it’s dficult to quanty that unless you have a race to really find out where you’re at.“I really didn’t know how it would go. I was half expecting to come out and run something like secs, so when I saw my time I was really thrilled about it.#It’s encouraging.”Clark’s main aim for  is to represent Great Britain at the delayed Olympic Games in Tokyo.But, on the basis of last weekend’s performance, she could be in line for a place at the European indoor championships in Poland should the event go ahead.She said: “I’d consider it for sure, but it’s all about getting ready for the summer.#But getting as many races as possible just now would probably be beneficial.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. vw, px"

Thanks you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging timeWe value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Sir,As always in such matters, the UK-EU Brexit deal will iniably throw up more than a few surprises aside from the usual headlines heralding a British #victory# in negotiations.The fact that, for example, seed potatoes are not to be included in the deal will be deeply damaging to our rural economy.Scottish seed potato farmers are one of the biggest exporters of potatoes in the world, from which crops are grown to be used in the production of the ware crop, chips and crisps. The sector in Scotland accounts for around  per cent of UK production and is worth about £ million annually.One fth of these exports go to the EU, amounting to more than , tonnes a year.This is clearly a disastrous Brexit outcome for Scottish farmers and like all other aspects of Brexit, foisted on Scotland against its will.A terrible negotiating failure on the part of the Tory government, and a devastating blow to an extremely valuable part of Scotland’s farming industry, I am sure it will not be the first damaging impact to be highlighted once the deal is fully analysed.Alex Orr, EdinburghSir,The report on the Piers and Harbours Asset Management Plan and Fees and Charges –  , submitted to the Argyll and Bute Council Harbour Board meeting of December ,  makes interesting reading.At a time when budgets are tight and councils have had to make hard decisions about where to cut services, it is dficult to understand why the council budget should be used to supplement the funding of dedicated ferry infrastructure for which CMAL should be responsible.The asset management plan allocates £,, for planned marine infrastructure works for the year  , of which only £, , is devoted to multi-use facilities. The remainder, £,,, is mostly allocated to single-use ferry facilities, and a huge proportion of that is to provide overnight parking for CalMac ferriesreaders will have to make up their own minds about the merits of spending £,, for an overnight berth at Fionnphort, and £, on a feasibility study for a breakwater at Lismore.CMAL pay back around half of the £,, to the council through harbour dues for the use of council-owned piers, however, that still leaves a whopping £ million gap in the required funding.If past experience of other CMAL projects is anything to go by, the planned eight per cent increase in council harbour fees and charges up to   is not going to cover it.Fergus Gillanders, KilmelfordSir,Last year, , was challenging and, although many people like to give generously to charity at Christmas time, it may have been dficult to make a donation this festive season.It#s not too late # you can still help support the Royal National Institute of Blind Peopleby collecting and donating used stamps from cards and parcels you may have received.Your stamps will be recycled and turned into vital funds that will help RNIB support children with vision impairment. By donating your stamps, you can help to make good things happen for these children, like ensuring they receive a letter from Santa in a format they can read in future.To get involved and receive a pre-paid envelope for your stamps, visit www.rnib.org.uk stamps or call   .After this, all you need to do is send your stamps using RNIB’s freepost envelopes, and they’ll take care of the rest. It really is that simple!Show your support for RNIB this festive season by collecting stamps and help to make le better for blind and partially-sighted people.Thank you.Vanessa Feltz, broadcaster and television personalitySir,For many people, Christmas is usually a time for catching up with friends, raising a glass and embracing loved ones. But this Christmas would have been very dferent for most families across the UK, including those sadly affected by heart and circulatory diseases.There are around , people in Scotland living with heart and circulatory diseases, including coronary heart disease, stroke and vascular dementia. We know from the millions of people who have turned to us for support in  that so many people with heart and circulatory diseases are worried about their greater risk from Covid- and that many have been shielding.With your support, we’ve worked tirelessly to be there for people – extending our Heart Helpline’s opening hours, providing valuable Covid- information and continuing to fund research with the promise of improved treatments. Even over Christmas our Heart Helpline was open for those who needed us most.But we need your support now more than ever to continue this vital work. The closure of our shops and cancellation of fundraising events has had a devastating impact on our funds, putting le-saving discoveries in peril. We expect our income for  to be cut in half.Traditionally, Christmas is a time for giving and generosity. Whilst some Christmas traditions may have changed in , we hope this one hasn’t # your support will help us to continue to fund research and support millions of people with heart and circulatory diseases at a time when they really need us.Dr Charmaine Grfiths, chief executive, British Heart Foundation

He is a part-time music teacher, with a passion for jazz, whose le has not gone the way he expected.Long story short, he gets an opportunity to play with his dream band. title: letters to the editor january 8 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall.
