Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Last week saw the conclusion of the serialisation of Campbeltown soldier Gunner Neil MacLean#s previously unpublished prisoner of war diary.Gunner MacLean was captured in June  following the st Highland Division’s surrender at St Valéry-en-Caux during the Second World War.A copy of his diary, several photographs and a poem, below, which was written during his time as a prisoner of war, were supplied to the Courier by Neil’s son Calum, who knew nothing of their existence until after his father died aged .On the th day of June with old Blighty so gay,We were then taken prisoners, I’m sure you all know,We all did our best, we all want you to know,The above photograph shows Neil and the men of the Campbeltown-based  Anti-Tank Battery, which served alongside the st Highland Division in France in , at a reunion in Campbeltown around .Many of the battery members, all from the Territorial Army, were captured when the majority of the st Highland Division surrendered to the German forces, but some made it back to Britain and were later sent to the Far East.This photo shows, back row, from left: Malcolm Campbell, Robbie McArthur, John McNaughton, Duncan McIntyre, Duncan McIntyre, John McKinlay.Second back row: Jock McKay, John Shaw, John Robertson, Duncan McLaughlin, Alex McKinven, Alex Robertson, John Mathieson, James Morrans, Willie Cook, Hamish Lynn, Jacky McKinven, Dougie McDonald, Neil MacLean, Davie Finn, John McNaughton, Jimmy Finn, John McCallum, Andy Mathieson, Dan McKinven, Sergeant Major John McDougall, Willie McCormick.Second from front row: Willie Anderson, John McMillan, James Shaw, Finlay Huie, Hamish Morrans, Captain George Lewis, Major Macalister-Hall.Front row: Charlie Morrison, Neil Gillies, Duncan McCallum, Jimmy Cunningham, Berty Cook, Jimmy McIvor.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Hector’s starring role in TV lighthouse specialMull of Kintyre Lighthouse will be featured in a film to celebrate  years since the first light was lit in .Produced by Caledonia TV, the BBC programme is narrated by Dennis Lawson and Campbeltown#s Hector Lamont, who was previously a lighthouse keeper. His we Esther also features on the programme.The film takes viewers through the remarkable achievements of the Lighthouse Stevensons over the course of five generations from the late s to the early s.The programme also features Fair Isle South Lighthouse, which was the last in Scotland to be automated in , with interviews from the keepers serving at the time. It will be aired on March  at pm.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOPressure piled on for quick Irish ferry decisionPressure was growing earlier this week on the Scottish Secretary to give Caledonian MacBrayne the go-ahead to operate the proposed ferry link between Campbeltown and Ballycastle in Northern Ireland.Scottish Office officials are said to oppose state-owned CalMac’s participation in the project.But earlier this week it was revealed they had asked CalMac to submit a business plan for the route. The news was welcomed by the prospective Conservative candidate for Argyll and Bute, Mr Ralph Leishman.He told the Courier: ‘This is a definite step forward and knocks on the head suggestions that the Scottish Office is totally opposed to CalMac as the operator on this route.’Scottish Office reservations are believed to centre on proposals to use the MV Claymore on the route. This would mean £, would have to be spent upgrading another vessel for relief work for its west coast services.They are also said to be concerned that no private firm appeared to be interested in running the service all year-round.CalMac’s participation in the project has been backed by politicians on both sides of the Irish Sea.Both Scottish Secretary Mr Michael Forsyth and Prime Minister Mr John Major were believed this week to have been lobbied at Westminster by CalMac’s supporters.Northern Ireland secretary Sir Patrick Mayhew is said to be among those who have contacted Mr Forsyth to support CalMac’s involvement.The project supporters have been asking the Scottish Office to consider the economic benefits the ferry could bring to Ballycastle and Campbeltown, which are both areas of high unemployment. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.By Jingo, Keith Abendroth has some brass neck in blaming the catastrophe facing Scottish fishing businesses on the dastardly EU. His solution is even more batty.Driven by resentment and sepia-tinted post-Empire English nationalism, cloaked in talk of Britain and the UK, the Tories have jemmied the UK out of the world’s largest and most successful single market.Having placed the UK as a #third country# outside the EU, alongside Somalia and Kazakhstan, it is not the EU to blame for the barriers to free trade, Mr Abendroth, but the UK government and those who parroted the cruel myths of Brexiteer #sunny uplands#.Mr Abendroth suggests that the fishing industry merely sells into the domestic market as a replacement to EU trade, without thought to the timescales required to repurpose supply lines and create a viable home market # evenit could be done fishing businesses would already be bankrupt.Scotland’s economy and the living standards and opportunities of Scots have been thrown under the wheels of England’s red Brexit bus. Never have the consequences of permitting Westminster to rule our country been more stark.But the time is coming when Scotland will have the historic opportunity to regain the huge benefits of EU membership and become a normal, thriving, independent state at the heart of Europe. There is an empty seat at the top table in Europe # and it won’t be empty for long.Ron Wilson, secretary, Kintyre SNP.Remember the closing stages of the Brexit negotiations  Boris Johnson pretended he was holding out to get the best deal for fishermen. In the end he agreed a deal that the Scottish Fishermen’s Federation described as #desperately poor# and #the worst of both worlds#.Fishermen are restricted to catch fewer fish in most key species. Lorries carrying stocks that have been caught were left to sit at Larkhall – unable to penetrate the new fog of bureaucracy. Scottish fishermen are forced to land the fish they can catch in Denmark – grim news for Scottish fish processors.Instead of trying to fix the problem, Tory Minister Jacob Rees-Mogg says the fish are happier to be British. Of course they are – the fishermen aren’t catching them.The Tories must sort out this mess they have created. Our fishermen and fish processing workers deserve better than silly remarks about happy fish.Councillor Alan Reid, Cowal ward.Keith Abendroth is spot on with his call for the fishing industry in Campbeltown to supply the home market.During my three-and-a-half years in the town it was possible to buy directly from the boat on occasion but it was nigh on impossible to buy fresh live lobster in the town#s fish shop.When I was new to the town , I experienced some shocking service at the some of the small retailers who I always endeavour to support. It is easier to get a full range of seafood and fish in Peebles, about  miles from the sea, which has an excellent fish shop supplied from Eyemouth on the East Coast.Much Welsh shellfish is sent by air to Europe. I often wondered why lorries trundled from Campbeltown across the Rest and Be Thankful and all the way to the English Channel crossings.Much of the st century supply chain is a mystery to me. For instance, much Pacic wild salmon is processed in China before being exported to the UK.  It is an excellent alternative to the farmed version at roughly the same price.Surely a town with an airport could develop a sea product freight service or is it simply down to volume, weight and cost Mark Davey, Peebles.Two weeks ago, at Campbeltown Free Church, we received a letter of thanks from Blythswood Care for filling shoeboxes to support the  Shoe Box Appeal.However, we are aware that many who contributed do not belong to Campbeltown Free Church.So, through the pages of the Courier, can I thank them for their kindness towards people they have never met but whose lives have been enriched by their generosity Dr Rodger M Crooks, Campbeltown Free Church minister.Like many, many other residents in Argyll and Bute I have received through the post a bizarre leaflet from the Liberal Democrats. Bizarre, because it promotes a candidate standing in a completely dferent seat # Caithness, Sutherland and Ross.Meanwhile, the good folk of Caithness, Sutherland and Ross have been equally mystied as to why the hapless Lib Dems have sent them leaflets promoting a candidate in Argyll and Bute!The Lib Dems have certainly lost their way when it comes to their policy on the EU # but it seems that they#ve lost their way in Scotland too.Les Wilson, Islay.Earlier this month the Prime Minister announced a third national lockdown. Although necessary, these measures mean many of our veterans will be facing the next several weeks – or months – completely alone.And while the vaccine rollout out across the country provides some hope, social isolation and loneliness poses a real threat to our elderly this winter, among them many former RAF personnel and their partners supported by the fund.To help combat this, last year the RAF Benevolent Fund introduced a weekly Check and Chat service to support members of the RAF Family experiencing loneliness. I speak to one such gentleman every Tuesday. He lives alone and spent much of  totally isolated and, for him, this service truly is a leline. We chat about what he’s been up to, what he’s cooking for tea, to his time in the RAF and often I’m the only person he will speak to for days.The fund also organises weekly telephone friendship groups, provides access to a listening and counselling service, relationship counselling support, and an online wellbeing portal to help support emotional wellbeing amongst the veteran community.Throughout the pandemic, many of us have learnt more about our neighbours and local community. That’s why we are calling on the people of Scotland to consider whether they know any RAF veterans, or their spouses or widows, who may be experiencing loneliness.To refer someone to the RAF Benevolent Fund, please visit rafbf.org or call   .Air Vice-Marshal Chris Elliot, chief executive, RAF Benevolent Fund.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.As the Investigative Support Officer for Scotland for the National Wildle Crime Unit , PC Gavin Ross will be a source of expertise in wildle crime at both the local and national level. He will work with inidual police wildle liaison officers, NGOs, the Scottish Government, NatureScot, RSPB, the SSPCA and Scottish Land and Estates. The position is funded by NatureScot.PC Ross was the community police officer for Dunbar, and has  years of police service and an extensive background in wildle crime issues, community policing, problem solving and educational work.Minister for Rural Affairs and the Natural Environment Ben Macpherson MSP said: #Wildle crime is despicable and tackling it has been a long-standing priority for the Scottish Government.#We work closely with a number of agencies to ensure perpetrators are brought to justice.#The Animals and Wildle Act, which recently became law, increases the maximum penalties for the most serious wildle crimes and extends the time available to Police Scotland to investigate.#The work of the National Wildle Crime Unit is hugely valued by communities across Scotland and we are committed to supporting it. I look forward to working with PC Ross in the future and congratulate him on his new role.#PC Ross said: #When I was in Edinburgh, very early in my service, I became involved in investigating wildle crime because of my interest and experience in this area. I’ve been a part-time wildle crime officer throughout my whole service and the new job is the pinnacle of my career.#I worked very hard preparing for my interview and was very keen to secure the job, which is a dream post. I am looking forward to settling into the role and working with all the dferent partner agencies which are so important in the fight against wildle crime.#In the six weeks I’ve been in post I’ve concentrated on meeting many of the partner agencies we work with in wildle crime. Unfortunately most of the meetings have had to be done virtually, but I feel they have all been really positive and I look forward to building on these initial foundations, especially when we can meet face to face.#The head of the NWCU, Chief Inspector Hubble added: #I was extremely pleased when PC Ross was successfully appointed as our new Scottish ISO and I am sure he is going to be a valuable asset to policing wildle crime.#Andy Turner, NatureScot wildle crime officer, said: #Eliminating wildle crime is huge priority for us, which is why we’ve provided funding for this post since . Wildle crime doesn’t just cause irreparable damage to Scotland’s nature, it also affects tourism, which in turn impacts on the economy.#We are committed to working with NWCU, Police Scotland and other members of the Partnership for Action Against Wildle Crimeto tackle this challenging issue.#We worked closely with Gavin’s predecessor, Charlie Everitt, to prevent wildle crime and raise awareness. I look forward to continuing to this important work with Gavin and the NWCU in the future.#NWCU’s main role is to assist in the prevention and detection of wildle crime by obtaining and distributing information from a wide range of organisations and by helping police forces investigate wildle crimes. NWCU also produce analysis which highlights local or national threats.The appointment of PC Ross comes after the retirement of PC Charlie Everitt, who had spent the last  years developing the role of Scottish ISO within the National Wildle Crime Unit.PC Everitt furthered countless operations, provided expert advice to police wildle liaison officers and acted as the key central point of contact between the police and a vast range of partner agencies.He was well known throughout the Scottish wildle crime arena and his professional knowledge, enthusiasm, and willingness to assist were beyond question. PC Ross recognised he had #big shoes to fill#.

story: The Belters, who had twice beaten teams from a higher league to reach the second round in their debut in the historic competition, dared to dream of an even more famous triumph after taking a third-minute lead at the Bayview Stadium courtesy of a long-range Steven Thomson free-kick.Tranent looked set to hold their lead until half-time against the Fers ndash who play three isions above them in Scottish League One ndash only to be stung by two goals just before the break from Scott Agnew and Craig Watson, turning a - lead into a - deficit.And two quickfire second-half goals from Agnew to complete his hat-trick ended Tranents hopes of reaching the third round, with Kevin Smith adding some extra gloss to make the final score - to East Fe.

title: east-lothians-football-clubs-see-remaining-january-matches-postponed
story: Concerns about the ldquoescalating coronavirus situation have seen football from below the Scottish Professional Football LeagueChampionship down, including the East of Scotland Football League , postponed for the rest of January.The Scottish Football Associationboard met on Sunday to discuss the pandemic "and its impact on the national game at all levels".A statement on the governing bodys website said: ldquoFollowing a meeting between the Scottish FA and the Minister for Public Health Sport and Wellbeing, both parties have agreed to impose a temporary suspension of all football beneath the Scottish Professional Football League Championship, encompassing all predominantly part-time tiers of the Scottish professional pyramid, from midnight tonight.ldquoThe impacted leagues are: SPFL League One, SPFL League Two, Scottish Womenrsquos Football Premier Leagues   , Highland League, Lowland League, East, West  South of Scotland Leagues, Scottish Junior FA Leagues and the North Caledonian League.Tranent Juniors were the only East Lothian team in action over the weekend as their Scottish Cup adventure came to an end at East Fe.The Belters, who sit top of the EOSFL Premier Division, were due to face Dundonald Bluebell this weekend but no games will now take place until February  at the earliest.Fellow Premier Division sides Musselburgh Athletic and Dunbar United were due to face Sauchie and Crossgates respectively this weekend, while Ormiston were due to welcome Kirkcaldy and Dysart, and Haddington Athletic were facing St Andrews in the First Division Conference A.Preston Athletic were not scheduled to have a game this weekend.However, those games will all now need to be rescheduled.Rod Petrie, Scottish FA president, said: ldquoThe Scottish FA is well aware of the efforts all clubs take to comply with the exacting protocols that were conditional on elite football being given an exemption to continue amid the pandemic.ldquoNonetheless, the continuation of football at all levels has weighed increasingly heavy on me as president, my colleagues on the board and the joint response group as we have watched the new strain of the virus spread rapidly.ldquoWhile national sport has been afforded the privilege of elite sporting exemption, the risk of mass transportation of untested, largely part-time players is something that cannot be sustained as the cases continue to rise and available hospital beds become increasingly scarce.ldquoAfter discussions with the SPFL, the Premiership and Championship will continue on the proviso that both adhere to the existing testing regime.ldquoThe vast majority of teams in those isions are full-time professional clubs and so the risk of transmission remains manageably low.ldquoThe cost implications to lower-ision clubs was one factor but so too the realisation that many ndash with some notable exceptions ndash consist of part-time players who are either prevented from working due to the virus or have to work.ldquoIn either case, the risk is currently too great amid the developing nationwide spread of the virus.

title: letter-week-new-super-school-prestonpans-blindwells
story: Under the local plan, construction of a new secondary school is already scheduled to cope with the later stages of the Blindwells development.Pending this new school being built, I imagine unsightly and unsatisfactory Portakabins will be added onto the already dilapidated Preston Lodge building, overcrowding its school hall and other facilities.Would it not be far better to establish a new purpose-built super school, which would be able to cope with the combined school populations of both the Blindwells and Prestonpans areas, and also to start building this much earlier than currently envisaged I recently suggested this idea with a local councillor. While he liked the concept in principle, he indicated that the current agreement with the Blindwells developer meant that the council would not be able to afford going ahead with such a project.This is because the developer is not obliged to produce any funds for a secondary school at Blindwells until a much later stage in the projectrsquos development.However, I have read recently in the Courier of least one instance ndash the postponing of improved access roads ndash where the council appears prepared to be bending over backwards to accommodate changes in the Blindwells development plan to suit the developer. Would it not be reasonable for the council to ask the developerthey might now reciprocate, by acceleratingtheir contribution to the arearsquos school estate Building a new secondary lsquosuper schoolrsquo earlier than now planned would substantially enhance the sales value of the new houses in the first stages of the Blindwells development, as well as provide a better pupil experience for everyone in the Prestonpans cluster.Angus TullochLongniddry

title: date-announced-opening-drive-through-covid-vaccination-centre-queen-margaret-university
story: It will have  stations and be capable of vaccinating , people a week.Other large centres in Edinburgh and West Lothian will begin vaccinating patients on Monday as part of wave two of the national vaccination programme.These include the Edinburgh International Conference Centre , which will be capable of vaccinating more than , people a week.East Lothian Community Hospital, in Haddington, has also been named as a smaller, more localised vaccination centre, along with many other community hubs in Edinburgh, Midlothian and West Lothian.David Small, of NHS Lothian, said they had already vaccinated "the vast majority of the first cohort to be prioritised" in the Lothians."GP practices continue to deliver the injections as fast as their vaccine supplies allow," he said.ldquoThis is a signicant moment as we embark on wave two of the largest vaccination programme that has ever been undertaken.ldquoWe need to vaccinate as many people as we possibly can to help save lives and provide protection to help communities get back to normal."We therefore urge people to attend their appointment once they are notied of the details."NHS Lothian has been working with councils, health and social care partnerships and other partners in recent weeks to ensure the sites are ready.The centres are the first of a total of  to be rolled out across Lothian, including the community hospital in Haddington.People aged between - and those most clinically vulnerable will be given appointments to be vaccinated by their GP, while those aged between - and  to  will be invited into mass vaccination sites and smaller community venues for their injections.Patients are being urged to keep their first appointment in order to provide protection to as many people, as quickly as possible eventheir appointment venue may not be the one that is closest to where they live.Smaller community clinics will deliver vaccinations in the local area for people with complex needs or who, for other reasons, absolutely cannot and would not be expected to travel to a mass centre.If patients absolutely cannot keep the appointment they have been given, they are being asked to call the Covid- Vaccination Helpline on    to rearrange their appointment. If they are aged  and over, they should phone their GP practice to rearrange your appointment.

title: driver-slammed-touring-north-coast-500-lockdown
story: Adam Jarguz posted on a social media site for owners of the Seat Leon MK car that he had made the three-day road trip last week.Alongside pictures he had taken on his journey was a caption that read ldquoNC complete.He added that he camped on the route, as hotels and BBs were closed, and did not encounter anyone during the trip, using pay-at-pump services for fuel.Under current Scottish Government lockdown restrictions, it is against the law to leave your home for anything other than an essential reason, with people urged to avoid unnecessary travel.Mr Jarguz has been criticised by members of the public who live along the route and by the North Coast  Ltd company.Tom Campbell, executive chairman of North Coast  Ltd, said: ldquoWe strongly condemn any irresponsible or anti-social behaviour conducted by a minority of visitors on the NC and would urge people always to report such behaviour to Police Scotland and other relevant authorities in the first instance.Margaret Meek, co-founder of NC The Land Weeps social media page, said: ldquoItrsquos not a grey area:itrsquos illegal to go from East Lothianto the Highlands for a jaunt for non-essential travel.ldquoObviously he did not drive  miles on a round trip and not get out of his car. Itrsquos not rocket science.Ali Gillespie, from Inverness, who spotted the social media post, said: ldquoYou only need to look at whatrsquos happening in Barra to see what happens when Covid arrives in wee places where locals arenrsquot expecting it.ldquoSelfish in the extreme.Mr Jarguz could not be reached for comment.

title: steeplejacks-tackle-maintenance-st-michaels-church
story: The specialist team completed an inspection of the lightning conductors and steeple, removed vegetation and also carried out work on an opening where coverings had fallen inwards.The project was undertaken by Northern Steeplejacks, which is based at Newtongrange in Midlothian.The cockerel weathervane was refurbished under a previous contract.There has been a church on the site since the th century.The present church was built in  to the design of Robert Nisbet and the steeple is recorded as being by the architect William Sibbald, following his earlier design for that at St Andrewrsquos, George Street, Edinburgh, in .This project was to a large extent the brainchild of the illustrious minister of St Michaelrsquos, Dr Alexander lsquoJupiterrsquo Carlyle.The kirk stands on the site of a Roman praetorium and replaces a medieval church. It has an Adam-style ceiling and stained glass.The building was substantially altered to accommodate the innovative new trend in worship ndash a pipe organ ndash in . This Lewis organ was quite radical in its design at that time.St Michaelrsquos boasts some notable ministers in its post-Reformation history, such as the second minister, The Rev Andrew Blackhall, who was an accomplished composer of music.The Rev Alexander Carlyle was a pioneer of the Sunday School movement and his autobiography shed light on a turbulent period in Scotlandrsquos history.The Rev John Beveridge was a campaigner for the renewal of worship and distinguished himself by his devotion to duty during a cholera outbreak.In , St Michaelrsquos celebrated the th anniversary of the present building, which is listed lsquoCategory Arsquo, meaning it is of special architectural or historical interest and is an outstanding example of a particular period, style or building type.

title: weekend-coronavirus-vaccine-clinic-set-riverside-medical-practice
story: They will be invited to attend on Saturday to receive their jabs from GP partner Dr Catherine Cameron, nurses Diane Fyffe, Delia Marriott, Sarah Falconer and Gillian Fulton, and general practice paramedic Tracy Henry.Almost  per cent of the first priority group have been vaccinated already and, while Riverside and other GP practices across the country are still constrained by vaccine supply, the third vaccine allocation sent to Riverside was large enough to warrant a weekend clinic.Staff will soon start to vaccinate people aged - and those in the shielding group who are defined on medical grounds as extremely vulnerable from Covid-.The practice, based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, is the largest in East Lothian and one of the biggest in Scotland, with about , patients.Dr Joanna Stenke, GP partner, said: ldquoOur dedicated team are delighted to be coming into the practice at the weekend to get as many of the first priority group vaccinated as possible.ldquoGPs across Scotland were asked by the Scottish Government to vaccinate registered patients aged  and over who can attend the clinic in person and wersquore pleased to have been able to vaccinate  of this group already at Riverside. Most people have been delighted when wersquove phoned to offer an appointment, and we really enjoy making the call.She added: ldquoThis weekend clinic will see the majority of our remaining patients aged  and over vaccinated, with the remaining few to be vaccinated when we receive our next vaccine allocation.ldquoWersquoll then begin to offer vaccine appointments to registered patients aged - who can attend the clinic in person along with shielders of all ages. Shielders are defined as those who have already received a shielders letter from the government or their GP.Eligible patients will be contacted by phone by the team at Riverside. Patients should wait to be contacted to help the team get the vaccines out to patients as soon as possible.The next priority group, those aged - years, will also start to be vaccinated shortly - but this is currently planned to take place in mass vaccination venues and health board clinics rather than in GP surgeries.Queen Margaret University has been named as a mass vaccination venue.Local health board teams will vaccinate housebound registered patients and these patients should wait to be contacted by them direct.For more information about the vaccination programme at Riverside, including which vaccine is being used and a weekly update on numbers vaccinated, visit www.theriversidepractice covid--vaccination-underway-at-riversidePatients are being advised to continue to follow local and national restrictions after receiving the vaccine.A spokesperson for the East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership said: ldquoI can say that the vaccination programme in East Lothian is progressing well, in line with the planned national roll-out.But East Lothian MSP Iain Gray has described the speed of the Covid- vaccine rollout in East Lothian as a whole as ldquounacceptable.: Speed of Covid vaccine rollout labelled lsquounacceptablersquoThe latest figures show that , people had been vaccinated across the county up to Sunday, January  ndash . per cent of the countyrsquos population. This placed East Lothian as the third slowest council area in Scotland for vaccines being administered.John Swinney MSP, Deputy First Minister, insisted this week that the national vaccination programme was on track.He said: ldquoGood progress has been made on the delivery of the vaccine for over-s. We have got to  per cent of care home residents, who are most at risk of morbidity from Covid.ldquoWe are in a majority now in over-s and that task will be completed by the end of the first week in February.

title: stuart-rollo-wins-porsche-macan-gts-70-000-botb-competition
story: Competition winner Stuart Rollo, of Prestonpans, received the surprise of a letime when he was told he would be taking home a Porsche Macan GTS, worth about pound,.But his day got even better when he was then informed that pound, would be coming his way too.His online ticket cost just pound.The -year-old was celebrating after receiving a video call from Virgin Radio UK presenter Christian Williams that he had won the prizes in BOTBrsquos long-running Dream Car Competition.Stuart said: ldquoThis is crazy. I knew who Christian was as soon as I answered the call ndash I was just not expecting him to be ringing me!ldquoI always joke to my partner Suzanne that one day she will get a call from BOTB as shersquos my surprise contact. I just canrsquot believe itrsquos actually happened!Stuart, who works as a health and safety manager at Lothian Buses, has played BOTB for years and always wanted to win the Porsche Macan GTS because ldquoit has everything.ldquoItrsquos just the perfect car for me, he added. ldquoItrsquos big enough for the family, itrsquos luxurious, itrsquos powerful and itrsquos absolutely stunning.Stuart ndash dad to Melissa, , and -year-old Jacob ndashpaid just pound for his competition ticket online.Christian video-called Stuart and lsquotookrsquo the county resident around to the boot of his prize car where a briefcase stuffed with pound, in cash was waiting for him.Stuart said: ldquoOh my gosh, this is just crazy. It was all about the car for me but this is just the cherry on top.This money will go such a long way for us.ldquoItrsquos been a tricky year for everyone and Irsquom really fortunate to still be working but we as a family need something to look forward to.ldquoThe kids have always talked about going to America so maybe a big family holiday is on the cards.BOTB hands over the keys to two cars each week, as well as a lestyle prize. Other recent winners have bagged a quad bike, a holiday to Las Vegas and a gaming tech bundle.The company, listed on the stockmarket, was founded by William Hindmarch in  and has given away more than poundmillion worth of cars so far.Competition entrants select what luxury car they would like to take home, pay a small entry fee and then make an online lsquospot the ballrsquo selection which determines who wins.Christian, who surprises BOTB winners, said: ldquoStuart seems like such a lovely guy and Irsquom super happy for him.ldquoHersquos played for this car so many times and what a fantastic prize it is.ldquoPlus, the pound, cash is definitely going to come in handy ndash he could even buy another Porschehe wanted to!ldquoMassive congratulations again, Stuart!

title: mary-contini-column-food-thought-covid
story: To be able to buy vegetables from the likes of Crunchy Carrot in Dunbar or Phantassie in East Linton is my foodie heaven !It is probably more expensive to shop locally and, as you need to drive to dferent outlets, it does take longer.For hard-pressed working families, this is not always an option. A big supermarket shop, with selections of everything we need, is a necessary part of most householdsrsquo routine.This year, however, this never-ending choice and supply has clearly been disrupted. The perfect storm of pandemic, Brexit and bad weather has resulted in frequently empty shelves. Some products are unavailable.Prices are increasing. Recent reports of supermarkets recalling food ranges such as pre-prepared seafoods and cheese spreads because of risk of contamination indicate trouble in the system.The food journey to supermarket shelf is long. Ingredients are pulled together from multiple counties, even countries.The brilliant exercise in sourcing, logistics, and extending the le of ingredients has successfully given us the lsquowhat you want when you fancy itrsquo way of le we have become used to.But, having been forced to stop and reassess how we shop, eat and live, I suspect many families are keen to step back from this corporate sales pitch and rediscover the local delights on our doorstep.Steady queues at the doors of local food shops, increased numbers of local food delivery services and fish vans bringing an ever-increasing selection of fish from the pier to our kitchen sink is, to my mind, a positive outcome of a dreadful situation.Milk daily on the doorstep. Lucarsquos ice cream straight to the door.Whatrsquos not to like

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-january-26-29-1996-1971-1921
story: IT WAS uncleardeparting Post Office owners would send back a letter from America, reported the East Lothian Courier on January , .Thursday was a red letter day for Ross and Louise Searle when they arrived in Aberlady to stamp their mark on village le.The Searles, from Glamis in Angus, have taken over the local Post Office from the previous owners of three years, Derek and Gloria Hutchinson ndash who now plan to travel the globe.The Hutchinsons are taking early retirement as they both near  and aim to start their voyage in America, and work their way from West to East, dropping in on friends who are scattered around the world.But the couple want a home base toto and are searching for a house in Aberlady or Gullane before they start their adventures abroad.Derek is a Geordie who came to settle in East Lothian  years ago with Edinburgh-born Gloria....and  years agoAN INTERESTING array of events were scheduled to take place in Tranent to help raise money for the townrsquos Baths Fund, including a cabaret, as told in The Haddingtonshire Courier of January , .The fund-raising committee which has been formed to help raise money for the building of the townrsquos swimming baths is working hard and has arranged an interesting programme of events.Miss Christina Forrest, the secretary, told the Courier: ldquoWe are going to have a cabaret, supper and dance in the Tranmare Hotel on March  and we are going to try and make it a monthly event.ldquoWe have two mannequin shows organised for March also and we have started a tote double.The Baths Committee has tender documents Main, David Laidlaw, horsebreaker, Alderstone, was charged with having, on Monday, rd inst., in Court Street, Market Street, and Hardgate Street, driven a horse yoked to a dogcart furiously, title: assembly-rooms-developers-say-a-sin-let-deteriorate
story: Efforts to breathe new le into Dunbarrsquos B-listed Assembly Rooms have been ongoing for more than  years.Plans were turned down last September for the Church Street building to be transformed into eight flats, with new proposals now put forward for four flats instead.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department deemed there was ldquoinsufficient space within the curtilage of the application site to provide eight parking spaces when rejecting the previous plans.Alexander Williamson and those representing him have called on the local authority to approve the new proposals, which they described as ldquothe only course of action left.They highlighted the alarming condition of the empty upper building and said: ldquoAt present, we are managing to maintain the structure that said, last year we did have to take down the centre chimney as the sandstone had eroded and split the chimney, leaving it tilting.ldquoIf this had gone unnoticed the tens of tonnes of rubble would have fallen over  metres to the floor of the ballroom and probably crashed through the wood floor into the property below.: Previous plans for Assembly Rooms are turned downThe Assembly Rooms were built, via subscription, in  for town gatherings of neighbouring farmers. It now appears on Scotlandrsquos Buildings at Risk Register.Three basement flats are privately owned and occupied and not in poor condition.A supporting statement included within the planning application addresses the parking situation.It suggested that people were parking on Church Street and nearby Castle Street to take the bus or train where, as well as to get to the townrsquos High Street.However, the report added that there was other parking available nearby.It calls on members of the planning committee to visit the site and to consider at the history of the building.The report concludes: ldquoIt would be a sinwe were to allow this historical building to decline further.ldquoTo put in perspective for those not familiar with the history, the Assembly Rooms date back to , the same year as King George IV visited Scotland ndash the first reigning monarch to set foot on Scottish soil for two centuries ndash three years after Queen Victoria was born,  years before the Victoria Harbour, Dunbar, which was started in .ldquoAlso,  saw the completion of the Scott Monument in Princes Street.ldquoThe Assembly Rooms is also nearly  years older than the Forth Rail Bridge, which opened in . The year  saw the completion of the North British Station Hotel , some  years after the Assembly Rooms.ldquoElsewhere in the world, Napoleon died the year before in  nearly  years later the American Civil War started in  and the Russian Revolution was  years later in .ldquoDo we want to lose this historical building Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, had been pleased to see the previous proposals for eight properties refused.She said there was now ldquocautious support for the new scheme, although there were still concerns about changing the height of the roof and the arrangement of the windows.She said: ldquoI think in some ways it is a shame the design is not more innovative but that is not our place to say.ldquoI still think the overwhelming view is the whole site needs a whole solution to it but there is no point banging that drum forever.ldquoAt some point, we have got to unlock it.ldquoIf the players are not going to speak to each other, it must be better for the building to get a new roof and new windows than to remain an eyesore for the foreseeable future.

title: aldi-confirm-haddington-gateside-store-open-second-half-year
story: The supermarket giant has confirmed it plans to open several new stores in Scotland during , which will see the number of stores across the country reach .The new East Lothian store will be based at Gateside Commerce Park on the townrsquos western edge and will replace its existing store off Whittingehame Drive, which will close.Aldi also plans to create a further  jobs, including  roles in its new stores, in a boost to local communities throughout the country.Richard Holloway, regional managing director for Scotland, said: ldquoDuring an unprecedented year, our Aldi colleagues and thousands of suppliers rose to the challenge of feeding the nation with tremendous skill and courage.ldquoAs we look forward to , our commitment to investment and expansion in Scotland continues, and we are excited be to opening a further four Aldi stores during the year, and of course reaching our signicant th store milestone.ldquoWhile our focus very much remains in bricks and mortar shopping, the launch of our Click  Collect service in Scotland is perhaps one of our most signicant initiatives yet, expanding our existing eCommerce business to bring our full range of groceries online for the first time.

title: soup-kitchen-van-serving-help-people-musselburgh-area
story: Run by hospitality food service provider BaxterStoreyrsquos Chef Shack, and based outside Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre on Haddington Road, it provides free hot soup to iniduals and families from the Musselburgh area.The soup kitchen is open on Tuesdays and Thursdays, am to pm.Meanwhile, Musselburgh Area Partnership is funding initiatives to support people in the community, working with East Lothian Councilrsquos Connected Communities service.Pamela Martin, community development worker, said: ldquoWith lockdown in the county, we aim to provide additional support to iniduals and families.She explained that, through a call-and-collect system, people in the Musselburgh, Wallyford and Whitecraig communities could collect a four-person recipe bag with fresh ingredients to cook a healthy, nutritional meal.It was hoped this would enable families and iniduals to try out new foods and develop new skills and cooking techniques thanks to a weekly recipe.There is a discretionary charge of pound per bag, with one allocated to each household.A food pantry ndash a free, emergency and confidential service ndash is also operated on a call-and-collect basis by phoning   . Opening hours are Monday-Thursday, .am-noon.On offer are foodstuffs, toiletries, baby supplies, pet food and face masks.Soup and sandwiches are being distributed to elderly members of the Musselburgh community on Tuesdays and Fridays.The schemersquos other partners include the Mercat Grill in Whitecraig and Tesco Extra Musselburgh.

title: windygoul-wombles-helping-clean-area
story: During lockdown and because of the restrictions in place, people have been staying closer to home and taking more opportunities to explore their locality,, something recognised by the grouprsquos founder, Alison Brown.When out and about with husband Craig and son Ethan last year, she noticed how one area in particular was covered in litter.She said: ldquoWhen the kids were out and about more I saw how bad the park behind Windygoul Primary School was and decided that I had to get a bag and tidy it up.ldquoIrsquom a person who doesnrsquot complain and just gets on with it but I thought that I better do something, and do it for other people, too.ldquoWe are living in a world where people are buying takeaway stuff more and spending more time outside.ldquoAbout  per cent of people are really responsible but there is that five per cent who continue to litter, and rubbish can also be blown into the sea.Alison, who lives on Lawson Way but was born in Northern Ireland, set up a Facebook group called Windygoul Wombles, and then held her first socially distanced event at the end of November.The page now has more than  members of all ages, with about - people attending each event.She also contacted and took inspiration from the Musselburgh street clean group.Ward councillor Gordon Mackett has been a big supporter of the Tranent group, allowing them to borrow litter pickers and a large dustpan and brush for clear up broken glass, and have access to pink bin bags. When placed next to a bin, the pink bags indicate to council staff that someone has taken part in a litter pick and the rubbish needs disposed.Due to the current pandemic, all those who attend an event are asked to remain socially distanced and or with their household group, wear gloves, and wear clothing suitable for the weather on the day.All the pickers and shared equipment used are cleaned thoroughly using antibacterial spray prior to each use.While the group started near Windygoul Primary School, which also provided the group with litter pickers, Alison decided to start covering other parts of the town.She hopes that, when restrictions allow educational activities and socialising among members, the group will be able to grow and take part in more litter-picking events.And some members have been taking matters into their own hands and picking up litter in their own time.Alison said: ldquoLots of people have been chatting to us when we have been out on litter picks and most of the comments we have received have been positive. People are really enjoying it.ldquoAnd thanks to the litter picks, people are spending a lot of time outdoors and socialising, while still staying safe of course.Thanks to their efforts, Alison is already beginning to see a dference.She added: ldquoHopefully people will start taking more pride in their local area again. I care about where I live and others should too. Some parts of East Lothian are very pretty.For more information, visit facebook groups windygoulwombles

title: cockenzie-house-gardens-receives-12-000-boost
story: Cockenzie House and Gardens dates back to the th century and has been turned into a community hub offering small businesses and groups spaces within its walls.It is one of more than  organisations to receive funds from HES as part of a pound.million recovery fund to help them cope with the impacts of Covid-.The house, in Cockenzie, will put the money towards repairswhich will ensure continued public access to the building which HES described as a ldquovibrant community hub offering studios for small business and artists and delivers a range of heritage and community projects within the grounds.The Historic Environment Recovery Fund is administered by HES on behalf of the Scottish Government.Alex Paterson, chief executive at HES, said: ldquoFrom museums in the Highlands to historic venues and buildings, we are pleased to support a erse range of projects theand breadth of Scotland as part of the Historic Environment Recovery Fund.ldquoBy helping to protect jobs, reopen historic sites and maintaining investment in traditional skills training and apprenticeships, we hope to support the wider recovery of the sector and Scotlandrsquos economy.Culture Secretary Fiona Hyslop MSP said: ldquoScotland is internationally renowned for the quality and ersity of its historic environment."Our historic environment plays a crucial role in defining who we are as a nation, supporting wellbeing and sustainability within communities and promoting a positive image of Scotland across the world.ldquoI am pleased that a wide range of projects will benefit from Scottish Government funding as part of the Historic Environment Recovery Fund."The support delivered through this fund will safeguard our shared heritage for future generations, protect jobs and help to strengthen Scotlandrsquos wider economic recovery.

title: haddington-corn-exchange-reopen-spring
story: An pound, refurbishment of the townrsquos Corn Exchange, which has put its main hall out of use for nearly two years, is almost complete.The work saw new roof lights installed in the main hall, as well as roof repairs and timber flooring replaced.A new storage area, new kitchen and additional toilets have also been created, with minor decoration of the building to be carried out.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWersquore pleased to report that our contractor Maxi has now completed the main refurbishment works in the Corn Exchange.ldquoThere remains a few outstanding detailing works to be completed and we look forward to sharing photographs of the finished space in the near future.The Court Street building has been a venue for everything from concerts by The Proclaimers and Fish to blood donation sessions and charity fundraisers.Councillor John McMillan, who represents the town, was hopeful that those using the building would notice a signicant change when it finally opened its doors.He said: ldquoI think there is a wee bit of finishing, fine detailed work and decoration to be finished.ldquoI am hoping we will get together with some of the key stakeholders and look at ways of using it better.ldquoIt is something that has been very firmly in my mind for a long time.ldquoIrsquom hoping, despite all the problems we have got with the new lockdown, that we will be able to look at better use, better management and better results for people out of having what is a great improvement.ldquoI think it has been needed and is money well spent.Mr McMillan was pleased to say that the character of the building, which dates back to , had been preserved despite the alterations.Work had been due to start in February  and be finished by title: stuart-housden-announced-new-scottish-seabird-centre-chairman
story: Stuart Housden, who was awarded an OBE in , has been appointed chairman of the North Berwick-based charityrsquos board of trustees.A former RSPB Scotland director and zoology graduate, he brings a wealth of charity experience and networks to the role, alongside a le-long knowledge and passion for nature conservation.The Edinburgh resident and father of three is a member of the National Lottery Heritage Fund, where he is an advocate of investment in Scotlandrsquos natural assets.Mr Housden, a keen birdwatcher, said: ldquoI am honoured to have been selected to chair the Scottish Seabird Centre, and look forward to meeting the many volunteers and supporters who have achieved so much in the charityrsquos first  years.ldquoScotlandrsquos marine environment, and the incredible numbers of seabirds that travel the oceans to either nest or winter around our coasts each year, are of truly international signicance.ldquoWe take them for granted at our peril, and they serve as a barometer of the health of our coasts and seas. Sadly, a number are in rapid decline.ldquoOur marine environment is under considerable pressure, from the effects of climate change and how we use the seas, with fishing, offshore developments and marine litter among the more obvious issues.ldquoThe Scottish Seabird Centre will, I hope, play a vital part in a future partnership working to find and encourage the recovery of Scotlandrsquos marine wildle resources, by informing more people about the positive actions they can take, so providing even greater benefits for people across Scotland.ldquoWe want these great marine wildle spectacles to continue to inspire future generations and enthral visitors from far and wide.And he added: ldquoThe charity is lucky to have such a dedicated and professional staff team, who are well placed to build on past successes.ldquoI would like to thank [former chairman] David Windmill for his wisdom and hard work these past eight years, he hands on the reins with the charity in sound health.Susan Davies, CEO of the Scottish Seabird Centre, added: ldquoWe are delighted that Stuart has been selected as our new chair.ldquoHis appointment is particularly welcome as we enter the United Nations Decades of Ocean Science and Ecosystem Restoration, and step up our own work to support these global commitments to reverse the damage to our marine environment and the decline in many of our iconic seabirds.ldquoAlthough this continues to be a challenging time for our charity, with the doors to our visitor centre once again closed under the latest Covid- restrictions, we are optimistic about the future.ldquoIn Stuart we have someone who is ideally placed to quickly pick up the reins from our retiring chair David Windmill, who expertly steered the charity for eight years, not least through these most turbulent times.

title: recharge-rehomed-ahead-move-permanent-base
story: Recharge, which is based on the townrsquos Church Street, will move to neighbouring High Street ahead of an ambitious bid to breathe new le into a town centre building.The former Co-op buildings at the junction of High Street, Church Street and Winton Place could eventually become home to a bistro bar, community hall and Recharge, as well as  new flats.In the meantime, Recharge will move to the former Premier store.Alan Bell, manager of Recharge, described it as ldquoa key moment for the group as they looked to secure a permanent base.The youth organisation has been working with youngsters aged - in the Farsquoside area since .Mr Bell said: ldquoThis is a really exciting time for Recharge as it allows us to plan and develop the services that we offer to young people.ldquoThe temporary accommodation is in an ideal location and also allows for us to continue to deliver our services without them being affected.ldquoEveryone at Recharge would like to say a massive thanks to George and Susan Thomson, who stepped in a few years ago to secure the short-term future of Recharge when the building was being sold and have now also secured the long-term future with a purpose built facility.Mr Thomson bought the former Co-op building, which was originally developed by East Lothian Co-Operative Society of Tranent, to be used as shops and warehouses, more than five years ago.Already, a section of the building has been developed, with a new post office and coffee shop.Now, plans are with East Lothian Council to transform the rest of the site.The ground floor would include four one-bedroom flats, as well as the bistro bar and community hall. Upstairs, on the first floor, would be Rechargersquos new home, as well as another four one-bedroom flats and four two-bedroom properties.The second floor would also have eight flats: three one-bedroom and five two-bedroom.Hillcrest Housing Association has been identied as taking on the social housing units.A design and access statement included in the plans highlighted that many of the spaces in the building were ldquodesperately neglected and in need of major repair.The state of repair is so poor at the northern end of the site that a section of the building would be demolished but would be replaced ldquolike-for-like in terms of scale.Previous plans showed there would be two shops and a soft play area on the site.However, ldquodue to the current Covid- pandemic, and the uncertainty that creates, the decision has been made to look again at the proposals.The design and access statement notes: ldquoThe events hall and Rechargehavehellip been retained as they create the community driven aspect of the development.ldquoAs before, the social uses will create vibrancy within the town and encourage people into the area throughout the day and night.

title: margiotta-confirmed-former-gullane-gym
story: East Lothian Council planning department gave the Edinburgh-based chain the go ahead earlier this month to move into Gullane Gym.Franco Margiotta, managing director, hoped work would start soon to create the new shop, with building warrants yet to be secured.He said: ldquoWe are all geared up for it. title: making-rights-real-set-bring-human-rights-groups
story: Clare MacGillivray, previously a Scotland committee member with the Equality and Human Rights Commission, is now interim CEO of the new group, Making Rights Real.Clare, who won an International Association for Community Development global community development ambassador award last year, spent  working on a scoping study for the new charity.She said: ldquoIrsquove been working in human rights and community development for about six years, so when I left my last job I went to the [grant maker] Baring Foundation, in England, and said that we needed resources to scope out a new organisation in Scotland, which would support communities to use the power of human rights.Making Rights Real came out of a project run by the Scottish Human Rights Commission, which supported residents in Leith to use a human rights-based approach to access pound. million of council investment into housing improvements.Clare said: ldquoWersquove had brilliant support from a whole range of organisations in a Scottish advisory group, like the University of Glasgow, the Scottish Human Rights Commission, PPR [an organisation in Belfast that has been doing such work for  years] and others.ldquoAt the end of the scoping study, we set up Making Rights Real.ldquoWe got funding from the Corra Foundation, Joseph Rowntree Charitable Trust and the Baring Foundation to kickstart the work in Scotland.The new charity, based in Edinburgh, will now liaise with grassroots organisations and charities to enable them to work in a ldquohuman rights-based way and to hold authorities to account for human rights issues or failures.Clare said: ldquoA lot of those will be in relation to things like poverty, housing, access to education or, for trans people, access to healthcare.ldquoThere are loads and loads of human rights issues which have been compounded by Covid.ldquoThis work is about empowerment of people itrsquos around providing people with the capacity to hold authorities to account.A community conversation held in March last year, before the Covid lockdown, as part of Making Rights Realrsquos scoping study, saw about  people from statutory organisations, and students at Ross High School and the Scottish Childrenrsquos Parliament, gather for a meeting in Farsquoside, which was attended by Anastasia Crickley, former chairwoman of the UN committee on the elimination of racial discrimination.Clare, who lives in Tranent with her husband and three children, aged ,  and , added: ldquoWe were talking about what are the main human rights issues here in East Lothian and whether there was interest in taking forward a human rights-based approach.ldquoOn the back of that there was a bit of interest but, obviously, because of Covid thatrsquos put things on the backburner.ldquoBut those are some of the conversations Irsquoll be picking up now that Irsquom in post.And Clare emphasised the impact of Covid on human rights issues, ldquoespecially in relation to economic, social and cultural rights.She added: ldquoPoverty, the right to food, the right to adequate housing, homelessness, the right to digital inclusion ndash wersquove seen children who are not able to access online learning. How has that been responded to  How do people in social care access the right to healthcare ldquoA spotlight is now being shone on those issues, which means we have an incredible opportunity to build forward better ndash I donrsquot like saying lsquobuild back betterrsquo because what we had before was rubbish.ldquoIf wersquove got this pot of money for public services, how do we make sure that the rights of the most marginalised are put at the centre See twitter Rights_Real for more information.

title: uk-close-normal-summer-according-expert
story: Dr Mike Tildesley, a member of Sage subgroup the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Group on Modelling , said scientists believed vaccines would block transmission of coronavirus but it was not yet known by how much.Speaking on BBC Radio rsquos Today programme, he said: ldquoIf we think optimistically,we follow the trajectory of the rollout of the vaccinehellip then hopefully we can be easing out of these controls that wersquove got in place sometime in March.ldquoBut I think even with that optimistic situation, it needs to be done relatively gradually.ldquoThe danger is of course as we do start to unwind controls then we offset the gains that we get from vaccination, so we need to be very careful.ldquoButthe vaccine rollout continues at high levels, and we do find that actually these vaccines are very good at blocking transmission as well as preventing severe infection, then wersquore in a good position.ldquoHopefully by the summer we can get back to something pretty close to what we have seen before the pandemic was normal.Dr Tildesley said the UK did ldquoneed to have these vaccines being pretty good at blocking transmission.He added: ldquoWe will start to gain much more information about that in the next month as we follow people who have been vaccinated and see what their ability is to pass on the virus should they get infected.ldquoItrsquos fairly early days yet.Askedvaccines needed to% block transmission, he said: ldquoI think probably not quite close to %, but I thinkwe have somewhere in the region of say  to %, then probably wersquore in a good place.He said vaccines were not % protective and some people would not have the vaccine.ldquoAs we ease the controls you get more mixing, and evena lot of the vulnerable population are protected then they have more risk, those that are not protected have more risk, he said.ldquoSo thatrsquos why a gradual easing of restrictions, combined with uptake of vaccine, is really whatrsquos needed.On Sunday, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said he was hopeful of a ldquofree great British summer.He said: ldquoIn six months we will be in the middle of, I hope, a happy and free great British summer.ldquoI have a high degree of confidence that by then the vast majority of adults will have been vaccinated.

Her last day will be August .A former pupil at the school, she became depute headteacher in  following four years at the University of Aberdeen studying English and completing her teacher training in Manchester.She was previously a volunteer parent helper at her childrenrsquos primary school in Lancashire and later became school governor during her time there.After completing her teacher training and ing to Scotland, she became head of English at St Margaretrsquos School in Edinburgh but, after completing her headship qualication at the University of Edinburgh and  years in the independent sector, she took up her depute role at North Berwick High.Mrs Rodger said: ldquoBy the time I retire, I will have been headteacher at North Berwick High School for eight and a half years, and depute headteacher for seven years before that.ldquoI have loved my time at North Berwick High School: it is a privilege to lead such a wonderful school and to work in partnership with all in our school community.ldquoI will certainly miss everything about North Berwick High School ndash the committed staff team, the supportive parents and carers and, of course, the pupils who are our key focus ndash but it is time for me to move on to the next stage of my le and for someone new to take over the helm and ensure North Berwick High School continues to go from strength to strength.ldquoThere will be time for reflection in the months to come for now, though, I will continue to give of my best as your headteacher.Mrs Rodger added that the reason for her early notice was to give East Lothian Council enough time to carry out the recruitment process for her replacement and allow her to have a ldquocomprehensive handover with the successful candidate during the summer term.

title: council-pressured-abandon-plans-cull-pigeons-dunbar-bridge
story: Plans were revealed last month for a potential cull of the birds before netting would be put in place under the rail bridge on the townrsquos Spott Road to stop the animals from roosting there.Concerns had been raised that birds were swooping from under the bridge and startling drivers, while the animalsrsquo excrement was also creating a slip hazard on the footpath.Now, a political party and a bird control expert have called on the local authority to look again at the options available.Among those calling for a rethink is the Animal Welfare Party.Kay Hamilton, Dowager Duchess of Hamilton, is a member of AWP and said: ldquoThe birds certainly shouldnrsquot be killed.ldquoThis is ridiculous and all out of proportion.ldquoNor should the council be thinking of installing netting, as we know many birds can become trapped in netting and suffer horribly before dying.ldquoAlternative solutions have to be found.Vanessa Hudson, leader of Animal Welfare Party, described moves to kill the birds or install anti-bird netting as ldquocompletely out of step with the times.She said: ldquoItrsquos  and time for us to accept that we share our spaces with wild animals, including pigeons, and humane solutions should be pursued.ldquoIt is an offence to cause unnecessary suffering to an animal, and nets cause nesting and visiting birds the most horric distress and injury before death by hanging, starvation or dehydration.Guy Merchant, of Bird Control Consultancy Services International , told the Courier that carrying out a cull would be ldquoa waste of time and money.Similarly, he suggested that putting netting under the width of the bridge could create other problems, such as trapping live birds, which could then lead to legal issues.Mr Merchant, who previously lived in East Lothian and operates his business from Cambridgeshire, said: ldquoThe very best thing you can do is mesh above the pavement area.ldquoYou completely mesh above the pavement area so you are excluding the birds from either side but leaving the central reservation open.ldquoThat means that the cost of the netting operation is dramatically reduced and, secondly,you kick all the resident birds out from the under the bridge they are going to go to peoplersquos properties in Dunbar and cause a huge nuisance."Mr Merchant said that left the birds to roost and perch in the central reservation of the bridge and their droppings would fall onto the road, rather than the pavement.At a meeting of Dunbar Community Council last month, it was revealed that work under the bridge was due to take place in mid-February.East Lothian Council said that the bridge was lsquohomersquo to ldquohundreds of pigeons which are causing problems for drivers and also fouling the footpath.It was said that work could take up to five days while the underside of the bridge was cleaned and re-netted in a bid to prevent pigeons from roosting there in the future.

title: covid-scotland-new-variant-symptoms-revealed-research
story: Data released by the Office for National Statisticsshow that some symptoms appear to be more commonin those who have tested positive for the new iant, through a survey of , positive tests from people in England.At the daily Covid briefing on Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon said that the new iant, which is more infectious,now accounts for an estimated % of all new cases in Scotland.The First Minister also told Parliament yesterday that Public Health Scotlandis examining evidence suggesting that there may be an increased risk of hospitalisation of people infected with the new iant.According to research by ONS, loss of taste and smell is less common in the new iant of Covid- - however, it is not non-existent.The following symptoms appear to be more common:In a group of around , people who had the new iant,  per cent said they had a cough, while  per cent said they were fatigued and  per cent experienced main in the muscles.In addition, , per cent had a sore throat.This can be compared to a similar survey conducted with around , people who had the old iant, where just  per cent said they suffered from a cough, with  per cent reporting fatigue.Muscle pain was prominent in  per cent of people, with a sore throat being reported from just  per cent.At the moment,experts say there is no evidence that any of the new iants cause more severe diseasein the vast majority of people who become infected with Covid-.But much like the earlier versions of the coronavirus, the risk of serious illness and death is highest for people who are elderly or have pre-existing health conditions.The UK iant has become the dominant coronavirus iant in Britain and has spread to more than  other countries.And the South African iant has also been found in at least  other countries, including Britain.Gene sequencing has so far uncovered  cases of this iant in the UK, with  of the cases not having any links to foreign travel.

title: road-closure-near-prestonpans-railway-station-planned
